model.name: Chicago
model.description: The jewel of America’s Midwest is rich in great architecture, of course (three of the country’s five tallest buildings—including the 1,450-foot Willis Tower—are located here), but there’s also excellent shopping in trendy neighborhoods like Wicker Park; extraordinary hotels (like The Langham, housed in a classic Mies van der Rohe skyscraper)…and exceptionally warm people. Not to mention the food scene, home to chefs like Grant Achatz (of Alinea) and Paul Kahan (the Publican). Who needs the coasts when you’ve got all this?

model.dontMiss:
###Eat###


[#restaurant: /restaurants/54947024287bf30b36b42032]|||
Native favorite [The Doughnut Vault](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/chicago/the-doughnut-vault) gets a new outpost in West Loop with multiple versions of their classic, old-fashioned doughnut and daily specials.
|||







###See###


[#activity: /activities/53eae5b8976f8f2d44d58b5d]|||
Explore the history of Chicago (as well as NYC and L.A.) through photography at the [Art Institute of Chicago](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/chicago/art-institute-of-chicago)'s current exhibit, "The City Lost and Found: Capturing New York, Chicago, and Los Angeles, 1960-1980, on view through January 11.
|||







###Shop###


[#shop: /shops/549471dc287bf30b36b42044]|||
New menswear shop [Notre](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/chicago/notre) just opened in Andersonville and will carry lines from Maison Kitsune and Patrik Ervell. 
|||







###Stay###


[#hotel: /hotels/54934133555714a72b32e067]|||
The city is getting a couple hip new hotels early next year when the Freehand and Virgin Hotel opens their doors. They'll join newcomers [Soho House](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/chicago/soho-house-chicago) and the Thompson.
|||


###FYI###


[#restaurant: /restaurants/5494710d287bf30b36b4203a]|||
Chicago got its first [Shake Shack](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/chicago/shake-shack-chicago) in River North last month, and it's been a hit, with lines out the door. 
|||

fields.bio: Hanya Yanagihara is the former editor-at-large at *Conde Nast Traveler* and the author of the novels *The People in the Trees* and *A Little Life* (March 2015). She is currently deputy editor of T magazine.

fields.name: Lauren Kilberg
fields.shortBio: Collector of maps, passport stamps, and freckles.
fields.bio: Lauren Kilberg is a freelance writer and blogger residing in Chicago. Her travels have found her camping near the Pakistani border of India, conquering volcanoes in the Philippines and being humbled in Haiti. She spent two years living and working in South Korea before repatriating to the United States, but not before taking the six-month scenic route home via a backpacking trip from Indonesia to India. In short, she's a collector of maps, passport stamps, and freckles.

cheatSheet.dek: The one-time home of architects Frank Lloyd Wright and Louis Sullivan is a design- and culture-lover's paradise, with enough stately facades and contemporary art to bring visitors back for repeat visits.

items.dek: This 19th-century building is an architectural icon with the world's largest Tiffany glass dome.
Ditch the bus: The best way to see Chicago's rightfully famous architecture is by boat.
Chicago's best contemporary art museum has feted artists like Alexander Calder and David Bowie.
Pay your respects to *La Grande Jette* and *American Gothic* at this monolith of an institution.

items.hed: Frank Lloyd Wright Home and Studio
items.dek: Tour the house and studio where the famed architect designed many of his best-known works.
The 25-acre addition to Grant Park has already gained fans thanks to design-focused amenities.

cheatSheet.dek: Chicago is home to one of the country's most dynamic restaurant scenes, with new spots from acclaimed chefs—Grant Achatz and Stephanie Izard among them—opening seemingly every week.

items.dek: Chicago's most elegant new restaurant was once the clubby canteen of the Chicago Athletic Association.
This Korean spot trades tablecloths and stuffiness for hard-to-find flavors and welcoming service.
Brendan Sodikoff's dim and narrow late-night spot offers decadent riffs on diner classics.
Grant Achatz's Alinea sequel transforms every few months, and reservations are ticketed.
This restaurant, a cross between an izakaya and an upscale spot, has creative riffs on Japanese food.
This buzzy spot is a cross between a barn and a beer hall, and offers a meat- and beer-heavy menu.

cheatSheet.dek: An elevated park akin to NYC's High Line, the 606 is a former freight line reborn as a greenway—anchored by the Bloomingdale Trail that bikers and walkers follow through Northwest Chicago.

items.dek: This small Logan Square cafe serves some of the city's best pies, both savory and sweet.
Gin lovers, this is your haven: This Logan Square spot focuses on the juniper-heavy spirit.
One of Chicago's prettiest parks is just a short walk from the Bloomingdale Trail.
Expect top-notch drinks and dishes from the first restaurant from the cocktail geeks at Scofflaw.
Fried chicken is the star here, with all the requisite sides (slaw, hushpuppies) vying for space.
One of Chicago's best bars is tucked into an alley in an industrial corner west of the Chicago River.

play.body:
[#image: /photos/53daab64dcd5888e145c411d]||||||

It’s [not the ocean](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/05/interactive-photo-quiz-great-lakes-oceans), but the beauty of Lake Michigan is that it practically laps against Chicago’s skyscrapers; even the larger beaches north of the city center are a quick taxi ride from pretty much any neighborhood. What this means, of course, is that even if you have lunch plans in Logan Square and dinner reservations on [Randolph Street’s restaurant row](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/chicago/2013/05/photos-randolph-street-chicago-restaurants), you have no excuse for skipping out on the latest water-sport craze: stand-up paddleboarding, where you stand on an oversized surfboard and use an extra-long canoe paddle to propel yourself around. Or the _latest_, latest water-sport craze: doing workouts such as Pilates and CrossFit while balanced on the board. If you fall off (_editor's note: You’re probably going to fall off_), who cares? It’s hot out! Try it here:











**[Chicago Paddle Company](http://www.chicagopaddlecompany.com)**



 CPC is among the most comprehensive of Chicago's SUP spots: Think private lessons; group lessons; kiddie lessons; "Margarita Monday;” ladies’ nights (hit the waves for 90 minutes, then on to a beachside bar); and sunrise social paddles, complete with a cup of coffee on the beach. Beginners can take advantage of experienced teachers, too: One founder is an elite rider for YOLO Boards, one of the biggest names in paddleboarding; the other has her instructor’s certificate from the World Paddle Association. If you’re confident SUPing solo, this spot also rents boards by the hour. _Rentals start at $30/hour; lessons start at $35/hour; social paddles $35 each. Hollywood Beach, 5800 N. Lake Shore Dr.; 312-970-0861._











**[Chicago SUP](http://www.chicagosup.com)**



 Chicago SUP is located on North Avenue Beach, the city’s unofficial party beach, and is your closest option if you're staying downtown. Take a lesson or rent boards by the hour, but beware: Once you’ve gotten some wave time, it’s hard to resist one of this group’s “expeditions,” ranging from a beginner’s-friendly paddle to watch Navy Pier’s iconic fireworks (Wednesday or Saturday nights; headlamps provided) to a four-hour Lighthouse Expedition Paddle that takes intermediate or advanced SUPers well out into open water to admire the skyline and more. Planning a bachelor party or company retreat? Chicago SUP can set up paddle time for groups as small as 7 and as large as 50. For fitness buffs, instructors from nearby gyms offer on-board yoga, Pilates, and SUPfit, a riff on CrossFit. _Rentals $25/hour; lessons $50/hour; expedition paddles $60 and up; workouts $25/class (some paddleboard experience required). North Avenue Beach, just south of Castaways Bar & Grill (1603 N. Lake Shore Dr.); 773-575-4787_.






**[Chicago S.U.P. Yoga](http://www.chicagosupyoga.com)**



 Yes, the idea of balancing in a tripod headstand during your first time out on a bobbing paddleboard is terrifying. But Chicagoan Mary Lou Cerami insists that paddleboards are perfect yoga mats—wide and stable—and that even beginners (and kids as young as 12!) shouldn’t sweat signing up for one of her 90-minute Sunday classes. If you’re going to trust anyone on that, it’s Cerami: She’s a registered yoga teacher and an American Canoe Association-certified paddleboard instructor. You’ll get a lifejacket to wear during the class and ample bragging rights after. _$50/class. Montrose Beach, 4400 N. Lake Shore Dr.; Hollywood Beach, 5800 N Lake Shore Dr._







**[Kayak Chicago](http://www.kayakchicago.com)**



 This 14-year-old kayak rental company has dipped its oars into the burgeoning SUP market. Rent stand-up paddleboards by the hour or day, test your balance at a 90-minute yoga class, or race other SUPers around a course designed by BIC Sport—no experience required, and you might paddle out of it with a medal or prize. Thinking lessons might be a smart call before you take to the racing circuit? Take intro classes with American Canoe Association-certified SUP instructors, or jump up to intermediate, where you’ll learn new paddle strokes, pivot turns, sprinting, and more. _Rentals $20/hour or $80/day; lessons $60/class; yoga $50/class; races $20. Montrose Beach, 4400 N. Lake Shore Dr.; 312-852-9258._











Photo: Todd Bannor/Alamy
play.dek: Stand up paddleboarding is the latest water sport craze to hit Lake Michigan's shores. You'll find plenty of places that will teach you how to paddleboard—or even how to do yoga out on those big, flat surfboards.

play.hed: 10 Reasons to Visit the Chicago Suburbs
play.dek: The next time you're in the Windy City, consider taking a day trip to explore all the fun activities in Chicago's surrounding suburbs.

items.title: [Bahá'í House of Worship](http://www.bahai.us/bahai-temple/)
items.caption:
Wilmette, Illinois
_____
Chicago is a city famous for its architecture, but the suburbs have a handful of worthy contenders as well. Just north of the city, the [Bahá'í House of Worship](http://www.bahai.us/bahai-temple/) in Wilmette is proof. Designed by architect Jean-Baptiste Louis Bourgeois, the Bahá'í Temple took more than 40 years to complete, spanning from its groundbreaking in 1912 to its dedication in 1953. Today, it remains the oldest surviving Bahá'í House of Worship in the world. The temple is open to visitors all year, and brief prayer services are held daily.

items.title: [Ravinia Park](https://www.ravinia.org/)
items.caption:
Highland Park, Illinois
_____
Home to the oldest music festival in the United States (the appropriately named Ravinia Festival), [Ravinia Park](https://www.ravinia.org/) attracts some 600,000 visitors each summer with its world-class concert series. The park was created in 1904 and over the past 100 years has hosted concerts by Louis Armstrong, Yo-Yo Ma, Ella Fitzgerald, Frank Zappa. Today, it serves as the summer home of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra. The open-air, 36-acre grounds invites concertgoers to pack a picnic and enjoy music under the stars.

items.title: [Arlington International Racecourse](http://www.arlingtonpark.com/)
items.caption:
Arlington Heights, Illinois
_____
[Arlington International Racecourse](http://www.arlingtonpark.com/) opened its doors and its track to thoroughbred racing in October 1927. Located in Arlington Heights, the park has had its more than 80-year history marked by successes and losses both on and off the track. It played host to the first $1 million race in 1981, then had its grandstand burn to the ground in 1985. It recovered, and in 2000, Arlington merged with Churchill Downs Incorporated. It continues to host thrilling races, concerts, and events annually.

items.title: [Chicago Botanic Garden](http://www.chicagobotanic.org/)
items.caption:
Glencoe, Illinois
_____
The 385-acre [Chicago Botanic Garden](http://www.chicagobotanic.org/) features 26 gardens spread across nine islands and surrounded by four natural habitats. This living plant museum hosts an array of permanent and seasonal gardens and exhibits. It's open and free to the public every day of the year. Be sure to also join the free photo tour of the garden led by a staff photographer the first Saturday of each month.

items.title: [Brookfield Zoo](http://www.brookfieldzoo.org/czs/flash/landing/index.html)
items.caption:
Brookfield, Illinois
_____
The 261-acre [Brookfield Zoo](http://www.brookfieldzoo.org/czs/flash/landing/index.html) is home to some 450 animal species. It first welcomed guests in 1934 and has been offering exhibits and events that encourage and support conservation efforts ever since. This groundbreaking zoo featured the first indoor dolphin exhibit in the nation, as well as the first indoor rain forest habitat in the world.

items.title: [Frank Lloyd Wright Home and Studio](http://www.flwright.org/)
items.caption:
Oak Park, Illinois
_____
Just outside Chicago in Oak Park stands the Frank Lloyd Wright Home and Studio. While Wright was not a native of the area, Chicagoans love to claim him as their own, and they're rightfully proud of the architectural marks he left on the city. Today, his Oak Park address serves as a museum, but from 1889 to 1909, it served as Wright’s home and studio. It has since been declared a National Historic Landmark and restored to its 1909 appearance. If you want to take a guided tour through his house, be sure to [order tickets in advance](http://cal.flwright.org/tours/homeandstudio)—they can go quickly.

items.title: [MB Financial Park](http://www.rosemont.com/mbfinancialpark/)
items.caption:
Rosemont, Illinois
_____
Minutes from O’Hare International Airport in the heart of Rosemont is [MB Financial Park](http://www.rosemont.com/mbfinancialpark/), a recently opened development with a lot to offer. It has restaurants, bars, a comedy club, movie theater, bowling alley, indoor skydiving facility, and the Big Ten Conference’s headquarters and museum. All of these are centered around a courtyard that plays host to movies in the park, a farmers' market, and an ice skating rink.

items.title: Cantigny Park
items.caption:
Wheaton, Illinois
_____
Just 30 miles outside of Chicago in the western suburb of Wheaton lies the 500-acre [Cantigny Park](http://www.cantigny.org/). The former estate of two renowned *Chicago Tribune* publishers (Joseph Medill and his grandson, Robert R. McCormick), the park features nature trails, a 27-hole golf course, a rose garden, and a preserved bit of history.

items.title: [Chicago Fire Soccer Club](http://www.chicago-fire.com/)
items.caption:
Bridgeview, Illinois
_____
Chicago is a city divided by baseball, united by hockey, and often frustrated by football. But in the end, it’s a city of sports lovers, and one of its teams proudly calls the suburbs home. The Chicago Fire Soccer Club is a Major League Soccer team based in Bridgeview. Spectators can cheer on the Fire at the 30,000-seat Toyota Park. Visit the [Chicago Fire website](http://www.chicago-fire.com/tickets) to view the team's schedule and purchase tickets.

items.title: Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory (Fermilab)
items.caption:
Batavia, Illinois
_____
[Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory](http://www.fnal.gov/), or Fermilab as it’s known locally, is a U.S. Department of Energy national laboratory. Though it's a functioning particle physics lab, Fermilab still has a lot to offer visitors both in education and the environment. The 6,800-acre site is home to nature trails, lakes, sculptures, wildlife, iconic architecture, lectures and concert series, folk dances, and even a resident herd of bison.

play.hed: World's Best Cities for Architecture Lovers
play.dek: Florence, Barcelona, Dubai, Seattle—these and ten other cities contain some of the world's best examples of design and architecture, including thoughtful urban planning and modern architecture buildings.

items.title: Miami, Florida: Art Deco
items.caption: Perhaps the most iconic on this list, [Miami Beach's Historic District](http://www.mdpl.org/ ) comprises the largest collection of Art Deco architecture in the world. To transform Miami into an ultramodern and luxury tourist destination during the 1920s and 1930s, architects turned to Deco's symmetrical and geometrical patterns, floral and animal motifs, and pastel colors to invoke fluidity and movement, which are synonymous with the city today.

items.title: Mason City, Iowa: Frank Lloyd Wright's Prairie School
items.caption: Inspired by the flat terrain and open sky of the Midwest, Wright's Prairie School was defined by bold, horizontal lines, low profiles, natural lighting, and an uninterrupted flow within and between interior and exterior spaces. He used this style when commissioned to design G.C. Stockman's house in 1908 (pictured here); neighbors (and some copycat architects) followed suit, which is why this small Iowa town has one of the [largest collections of Prairie-style homes](http://www.visitmasoncityiowa.com/html/wright.htm) in the world.

items.title: Tel Aviv, Israel: Bauhaus
items.caption: Recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, Tel Aviv's [“White City”](http://www.bauhaus-center.com/) contains 4,000 International Style buildings, many of which were built in the 1930s and 1940s. To accommodate the influx of Jewish immigrants fleeing Europe, German Bauhaus-trained architects integrated the modern style's affordable and functional building techniques with curved lines and a color well-suited for the Mediterranean climate to create a habitable city by the sea.

items.title: Seattle, Washington: American Arts & Crafts
items.caption: The early-20th-century American Arts & Crafts movement, whose ideals rest on hardwoods and artisanal handcrafting, found a natural home in the timber country of the Pacific Northwest. Nowhere are Craftsman bungalows more prominent than in West Seattle, home to the landmarked Bloss House (pictured here), and in Seattle's Queen Anne district, where the movement’s simple construction, balanced proportions, and matching gardens provided a sweet departure from the ornate Victorians of that era.

items.title: Chandigarh, India: Mid-Century Modernism
items.caption: Shortly after India's 1947 partition, Prime Minister J. Nehru tasked Swiss modernist architect Le Corbusier with designing an organized, progressive city: one that would break from past traditions from the ground up. Its planned supergrid, exposed masonry and concrete, and the eccentric sculpture-work that peppers Chandigarh has made the city a study for planning and design students around the world. Pictured here is the Punjab and Haryana High Court by Le Corbusier.

items.title: Florence, Italy: Renaissance
items.caption: It's hard to escape Renaissance aesthetics in Florence, the birthplace of the late-14th-century movement. The era's embellished but symmetrical and geometrical structures—columns and domes—and emphasis on realism and the human form departed from the irregular and severe lines of the Medieval period. They're most visible at Florence's Duomo and Basilica of Santa Maria Novella.

items.title: Barcelona, Spain: Gaudís Art Nouveau
items.caption:
Taking cues from modern Gothic and oriental techniques, the early-19th-century Catalan architect Antoni Gaudí wanted to create organic, urban spaces in the city he loved. A walk around Barcelona leads you through the largest concentration of his signature ceramic and stained-glass mosaics, as well as his undulating stonework and ironwork, which include Park Güell (pictured) and culminate in his unfinished masterpiece La Sagrada Família.

[Ogling Barcelona's Whimsical Architecture…](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2012/06/cities-architecture-design-lovers-photos_slideshow_Gaud-s-Art-Nouveau_7)

items.title: Istanbul, Turkey: Byzantine/Ottoman
items.caption:
A historic crossroads of culture and design, Istanbul's landscape provides a prominent display of its two conquering empires. Travelers needn't look farther than the Hagia Sophia mosque for the aesthetics central to both: the Byzantine dome and colored mosaics, and the Ottoman minarets and Islamic calligraphy.

See more [photos of cities for design lovers](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2012/06/cities-architecture-design-lovers-photos#slide=8)

items.title: Columbus, Indiana: Modernism and Post-Modernism
items.caption: Columbus, Indiana has a population of only 44,000, but it's a surprising trove of Modernism: The town claims more than 70 buildings designed by star architects, including I.M. Pei, Eero Saarinen, and Richard Meier. Credit for this belongs to philanthropist and architecture lover J. Irwin Miller, who, in the 1950s through 1960s, commissioned a revamping of the local churches, public buildings, and his own estate, leading the American Institute of Architects to rank Columbus sixth in the nation in architectural innovation and design. (Pictured here is the North Christian Church.)

items.title: Ditmas Park, Brooklyn, New York: Victorian
items.caption: The hundreds of free-standing 1900s Victorian single-family mansions transport visitors to another time and city, when developer Lewis Pounds helped create an ornate, middle-class pocket south of Prospect Park (on farmland previously owned by the Van Ditmarsen family), replete with wraparound porches and manicured lawns.

items.title: Dubai, United Arab Emirates: Contemporary
items.caption:
Over the course of ten years, Dubai's landscape has transformed. Home to the world's tallest building, the only seven-star hotel (pictured here, the Burj al Arab), and the only man-made archipelago modeled after the seven continents, Dubai's development has lured top contemporary architects like Zaha Hadid and Rem Koolhaas to feed into its outdoor design frenzy.

[…Or Dubai's Wild, Contemporary Structures](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2012/06/cities-architecture-design-lovers-photos_slideshow_Contemporary_11)

items.title: Marrakech, Morocco: Moorish Architecture
items.caption: The presence of _riads,_ palaces with interior courtyards and gardens and open skylights, are specific to Morocco and essential to Islamic design because of their emphasis on privacy. The lack of street-level windows and the use of clay walls also lends to the feeling of intimacy and grace. The density of Marrakech's _riads_—combined with the city's mosques, minarets, and mosaics—makes it an exceptional place to view the Moorish architecture of the 12th through 17th centuries.

items.title: Oxford, England: Gothic Revival
items.caption: Poet Matthew Arnold once called Oxford the "city of the dreaming spires." Taking notes from earlier Medieval stonework, the towers of Oxford's mid-19th-century Gothic Revival skyline define the city, embedding it with a sense of gravity and academic prowess—just like its namesake university.

items.title: Portland, Oregon: Green Architecture
items.caption: Although Chicago has the most LEED-accredited buildings in the U.S., Portland, Oregon, whose population is a quarter of the size, has the sixth highest number, making it the city with the highest concentration of green buildings. In addition, zoning regulations that preserve urban agricultural spaces, a bike-friendly layout, and energy-efficient homes whose designs take on organic shapes and materials make Portland—along with the design firms it is home to—a leader in sustainable architecture.

featuredStays.name: The Langham, Chicago
featuredStays.description: Located in downtown Chicago within walking distance of Grant Park and the Magnificent Mile, The Langham is a luxury hotel that's ideal for vacationers or the business traveler. This contemporary hotel is housed in one of Chicago’s landmark buildings and rooms have views of Lake Michigan and the Chicago River. There’s also a Mediterranean-inspired restaurant, a 67-foot swimming pool, and a spa to enjoy after a day of meetings, shopping, or sightseeing.
featuredStays.shortDescription: Sleek rooms are housed in a landmark building with views of Lake Michigan and the Chicago River.

featuredStays.name: Longman & Eagle
featuredStays.description: Over wild boar sloppy joes and tumblers of rye, foodies and rockers find common ground at Longman & Eagle, the year-old gastropub in bohemian Logan Square. Its six newly opened and—management forewarns—not entirely soundproofed guest rooms just upstairs are as nonconformist as the restaurant known to whip foie gras into hot chocolate. Guests check in with the restaurant hostess to get keys to an exterior side door leading to the hotel. A flea market aesthetic prevails in the randomly numbered rooms (4 through 76). Each is unique, but all have open plans with wood floors, glassed-in showers, vintage mirrors, original art, and Apple TVs programmed with a library of videos by local bands. Witty amenities include bedside books spanning Walt Whitman to Shel Silverstein, low-to-high minibar selections including Pabst Blue Ribbon in the can and Vosges Haut-Chocolat bars, salon hair products by Kevin Murphy and, in three larger rooms, retro tape decks complete with mixed tapes. Staffing is minimal—once you check in, there is no service other than housekeeping. But along with tokens for free whiskey, hotel residency seems to confer insider status with barroom staffers, who not only fast-track you to a table but offer advice on other area hot spots.
featuredStays.shortDescription: Foodies and rockers find common ground at this gastropub-cum-hotel in bohemian Logan Square.

featuredStays.name: Chicago Athletic Association Hotel
featuredStays.description: Chicago, always a mecca of sorts for American architecture fans, will become even more so in October 2015 when the city hosts its first Architecture Biennial. Fitting, since design diehards will have a new home base: the 241-room Roman and Williams–designed Chicago Athletic Association Hotel, in a meticulously restored 1893 Venetian Gothic building by Henry Ives Cobb, one of the most famous architects of the late 1800s.
featuredStays.shortDescription: One of Chicago's hippest hotels is located in a meticulously restored 1893 Venetian Gothic building.

featuredStays.name: Virgin Hotel Chicago
featuredStays.description: While amenities like free Wi-Fi, mini-bars stocked with street-level-priced goods, no fees for late or early check-out, and free room service are not necessarily new, it’s rare that a hotel offers them all under one roof. Enter the 250-room Virgin Hotels Chicago, billionaire entrepreneur Sir Richard Branson’s latest endeavor, now open in the city’s Old Dearborn Bank Building. The hotel itself doesn’t offer a ton in the way of innovation—but then there’s the rooms, which are arguably the most special and radical thing about the hotel. Divided into two “chambers,” rooms feature a dressing area and lounge-y bedroom separated by a thick sliding door. The idea here is to create two distinct spaces: one in which to get dressed and primped, and one in which to sleep and play. But you won’t have to pay suite-level prices; chambers right now are starting at $195.
featuredStays.shortDescription: Billionaire entrepreneur Sir Richard Branson’s latest endeavor is this stylish Windy City hotel.

featuredShops.name: Ikram
featuredShops.description: Admired by Michelle Obama among other influential figureheads, this iconic Gold Coast retailer is one of the few unique boutiques that consistently draws clientele from the coasts. Big-name designers hang their hats here, including classics from Chanel and Givenchy to edgier pieces from Proenza Schouler, Viktor + Rolf and Jean Paul Gaultier. The upstairs café is a see-and-be-seen affair offering a healthy respite from what could easily turn into some serious credit card damage.
featuredShops.shortDescription: This Gold Coast retailer consistently draws clientele from the coasts—including Michelle Obama.

featuredShops.name: Eataly Chicago
featuredShops.description: The newest addition to the Batali/Bastianich empire—the first U.S. outpost beyond New York City— features more than 20 different restaurants and bars spread over two floors, including the decadent Nutella bar and Bierreria, which features Italian classics like Peroni and Italian craft beers and microbrews (Baladin, Birra del Borgo) mixed in with the occasional American brew (Dogfish Head). Sure, you could try to do your grocery shopping here, but most come to Eataly to test-drive Batali-esque restaurants. The marketplace atmosphere is considerably more frenetic, but if you enjoyed, say, crudo and calamari at Esca, you can sample reasonable facsimiles at Eataly’s  Il Pesce & Le Verdure (fish and vegetable) outpost.
featuredShops.shortDescription: Stock up on the essentials—fresh pasta, wine, specialty olive oil—at this supersized Italian market.

featuredShops.name: Logan Hardware
featuredShops.description: The "hardware" in this hidden Logan Square gem are records—literal vinyl, and lots of it—for unbeatable prices. Bonus: The store sells quirky handmade dolls from a local Chicago designer, Mad Libs, and vintage games and toys. Unassuming gray doors near the register lead to the holy grail… Logan Hardware has its very own arcade museum stocked with game machines you can play for free, for as long as your heart desires. Adding to the charm: The restrooms are labeled with Pac-Man and Ms. Pac-Man logos.
featuredShops.shortDescription: The "hardware" at this Logan Square gem is vintage vinyl records—and plenty of them.

featuredShops.name: Urban Remains
featuredShops.description: Dealing exclusively in reclaimed and recycled materials, artifacts, and antiques, this vintage supplier has the monopoly on iconic pieces from Chicago's bygone industrial era (retired professional office furniture, garage remnants, retired front doors, etc.). There's both a showroom and an associated historical artifacts "museum" (items not for sale) dubbed Bldg 51.
featuredShops.shortDescription: This vintage shop stocks reclaimed and recycled items and antiques from Chicago's industrial era.

pinterest.dek: To mark the centennial of Wrigley Field, we recall some of the Chicago ballpark’s notable moments—from the planting of its famous ivy to the alleged Curse of the Billy Goat.
pinterest.hed: Looking Back: 100 Years at Wrigley Field

items.title: Weeghman Park, 1918
items.caption: Groundbreaking for Wrigley Field took place on March 4, 1914, and the stadium was completed just seven weeks later on April 23, 1914. The stadium was home to the Chicago Whales of the short-lived Federal League of baseball, and was dubbed Weeghman Park after Whales owner Charles Weeghman.

items.title: Wrigley Field, 1933
items.caption: After the Federal League folded in 1915, Weeghman bought the Chicago Cubs. A few years later, financial troubles forced Weeghman to seek out stakeholders, William Wrigley Jr. among them. Weeghman Park became Cubs Park in 1920, and six years later, after Wrigley had full ownership of the team, Wrigley Field was officially christened.

items.title: Go for the W
items.caption: The long-standing tradition of flying a flag bearing a _W_ atop the scoreboard after a winning game (an _L_ flag marked a loss) dates back to 1937, when the manually operated scoreboard was built.

items.title: Wrigley Field's Famous Ivy
items.caption: Wrigley Field’s signature ivy-clad outfield walls date to 1937. Bill Veeck, son of then-Cubs president William Veeck, Sr., purchased and planted the original ivy vines. Veeck Jr. came up with the idea a decade prior, as a 13-year-old popcorn vendor at the stadium.

items.title: Ivy Troubles
items.caption: So that pretty ivy covering Wrigley's walls? It can be the bane of outfielders who have to wrangle with a ball stuck in the vines. When this happens, it’s ruled a ground rule double.

items.title: Curse of the Billy Goat
items.caption: Ever hear the one about the Curse of the Billy Goat? That story dates back to game 4 of the 1945 World Series. Tavern owner William “Billy” Sianis had purchased a pair of tickets—one for him, one for his pet goat—but was asked to leave Wrigley because of the goat’s smell. The Tigers beat the Cubs that night, and in response, Sianis sent the Cubs owner a wire that read, “Who smells now?” Local reporters sensationalized Sianis’s insult into a hex: That the Cubs would never win a World Series again. Nearly 70 years later, it’s still true.

items.title: Wrigley at Night
items.caption: Though most major league ballparks installed lights for night games back in the 1930s and ’40s, Wrigley Field was the longest holdout. Its lights weren’t installed until 1988, which meant its first night game took place more than 50 years after the league’s.

items.title: The "Jewel Box" of Ballparks
items.caption:
The only active Major League Baseball stadium older than Wrigley Field is Boston’s Fenway Park, constructed just two years prior to Wrigley, in 1912. Both Wrigley and Fenway are known as “jewel box” parks: green seats, exposed brick and stone, and an intimate feel incomparable to modern ballparks.**


**




**


More on Wrigley Field:**




[The 30 Things to Eat at 30 Ballparks This Baseball Season](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/03/best-ballpark-food-baseball-season-2014_slideshow_chicago-cubs--wrigley-field_18)

pinterest.hed: 10 Reasons to Visit the Chicago Suburbs
pinterest.dek: The next time you're in the Windy City, consider taking a day trip to explore all the fun activities in Chicago's surrounding suburbs.

items.title: [Bahá'í House of Worship](http://www.bahai.us/bahai-temple/)
items.caption:
Wilmette, Illinois
_____
Chicago is a city famous for its architecture, but the suburbs have a handful of worthy contenders as well. Just north of the city, the [Bahá'í House of Worship](http://www.bahai.us/bahai-temple/) in Wilmette is proof. Designed by architect Jean-Baptiste Louis Bourgeois, the Bahá'í Temple took more than 40 years to complete, spanning from its groundbreaking in 1912 to its dedication in 1953. Today, it remains the oldest surviving Bahá'í House of Worship in the world. The temple is open to visitors all year, and brief prayer services are held daily.

items.title: [Ravinia Park](https://www.ravinia.org/)
items.caption:
Highland Park, Illinois
_____
Home to the oldest music festival in the United States (the appropriately named Ravinia Festival), [Ravinia Park](https://www.ravinia.org/) attracts some 600,000 visitors each summer with its world-class concert series. The park was created in 1904 and over the past 100 years has hosted concerts by Louis Armstrong, Yo-Yo Ma, Ella Fitzgerald, Frank Zappa. Today, it serves as the summer home of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra. The open-air, 36-acre grounds invites concertgoers to pack a picnic and enjoy music under the stars.

items.title: [Arlington International Racecourse](http://www.arlingtonpark.com/)
items.caption:
Arlington Heights, Illinois
_____
[Arlington International Racecourse](http://www.arlingtonpark.com/) opened its doors and its track to thoroughbred racing in October 1927. Located in Arlington Heights, the park has had its more than 80-year history marked by successes and losses both on and off the track. It played host to the first $1 million race in 1981, then had its grandstand burn to the ground in 1985. It recovered, and in 2000, Arlington merged with Churchill Downs Incorporated. It continues to host thrilling races, concerts, and events annually.

items.title: [Chicago Botanic Garden](http://www.chicagobotanic.org/)
items.caption:
Glencoe, Illinois
_____
The 385-acre [Chicago Botanic Garden](http://www.chicagobotanic.org/) features 26 gardens spread across nine islands and surrounded by four natural habitats. This living plant museum hosts an array of permanent and seasonal gardens and exhibits. It's open and free to the public every day of the year. Be sure to also join the free photo tour of the garden led by a staff photographer the first Saturday of each month.

items.title: [Brookfield Zoo](http://www.brookfieldzoo.org/czs/flash/landing/index.html)
items.caption:
Brookfield, Illinois
_____
The 261-acre [Brookfield Zoo](http://www.brookfieldzoo.org/czs/flash/landing/index.html) is home to some 450 animal species. It first welcomed guests in 1934 and has been offering exhibits and events that encourage and support conservation efforts ever since. This groundbreaking zoo featured the first indoor dolphin exhibit in the nation, as well as the first indoor rain forest habitat in the world.

items.title: [Frank Lloyd Wright Home and Studio](http://www.flwright.org/)
items.caption:
Oak Park, Illinois
_____
Just outside Chicago in Oak Park stands the Frank Lloyd Wright Home and Studio. While Wright was not a native of the area, Chicagoans love to claim him as their own, and they're rightfully proud of the architectural marks he left on the city. Today, his Oak Park address serves as a museum, but from 1889 to 1909, it served as Wright’s home and studio. It has since been declared a National Historic Landmark and restored to its 1909 appearance. If you want to take a guided tour through his house, be sure to [order tickets in advance](http://cal.flwright.org/tours/homeandstudio)—they can go quickly.

items.title: [MB Financial Park](http://www.rosemont.com/mbfinancialpark/)
items.caption:
Rosemont, Illinois
_____
Minutes from O’Hare International Airport in the heart of Rosemont is [MB Financial Park](http://www.rosemont.com/mbfinancialpark/), a recently opened development with a lot to offer. It has restaurants, bars, a comedy club, movie theater, bowling alley, indoor skydiving facility, and the Big Ten Conference’s headquarters and museum. All of these are centered around a courtyard that plays host to movies in the park, a farmers' market, and an ice skating rink.

items.title: Cantigny Park
items.caption:
Wheaton, Illinois
_____
Just 30 miles outside of Chicago in the western suburb of Wheaton lies the 500-acre [Cantigny Park](http://www.cantigny.org/). The former estate of two renowned *Chicago Tribune* publishers (Joseph Medill and his grandson, Robert R. McCormick), the park features nature trails, a 27-hole golf course, a rose garden, and a preserved bit of history.

items.title: [Chicago Fire Soccer Club](http://www.chicago-fire.com/)
items.caption:
Bridgeview, Illinois
_____
Chicago is a city divided by baseball, united by hockey, and often frustrated by football. But in the end, it’s a city of sports lovers, and one of its teams proudly calls the suburbs home. The Chicago Fire Soccer Club is a Major League Soccer team based in Bridgeview. Spectators can cheer on the Fire at the 30,000-seat Toyota Park. Visit the [Chicago Fire website](http://www.chicago-fire.com/tickets) to view the team's schedule and purchase tickets.

items.title: Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory (Fermilab)
items.caption:
Batavia, Illinois
_____
[Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory](http://www.fnal.gov/), or Fermilab as it’s known locally, is a U.S. Department of Energy national laboratory. Though it's a functioning particle physics lab, Fermilab still has a lot to offer visitors both in education and the environment. The 6,800-acre site is home to nature trails, lakes, sculptures, wildlife, iconic architecture, lectures and concert series, folk dances, and even a resident herd of bison.

fields.name: Lauren Kilberg
fields.shortBio: Collector of maps, passport stamps, and freckles.
fields.bio: Lauren Kilberg is a freelance writer and blogger residing in Chicago. Her travels have found her camping near the Pakistani border of India, conquering volcanoes in the Philippines and being humbled in Haiti. She spent two years living and working in South Korea before repatriating to the United States, but not before taking the six-month scenic route home via a backpacking trip from Indonesia to India. In short, she's a collector of maps, passport stamps, and freckles.

pinterest.hed: How to Enjoy High Tea for Only 15 Cents at Chicago’s Langham Hotel
pinterest.dek: In celebration of the hotel line’s 149th anniversary, The Langham Chicago will serve high tea at its original price, once a month, all year.
pinterest.seoTitle: How to Enjoy High Tea for Only 15 Cents at Chicago’s Langham Hotel
pinterest.seoDescription: In celebration of the hotel line’s 149th anniversary, The Langham Chicago will serve high tea at its original price, once a month, all year.
pinterest.socialTitle: How to Enjoy High Tea for Only 15 Cents at Chicago’s Langham Hotel
pinterest.socialDescription: In celebration of the hotel line’s 149th anniversary, The Langham Chicago will serve high tea at its original price, once a month, all year.
pinterest.body:
[#image: /photos/53daaa34dcd5888e145c3c0b]||||||

Talk of a British high tea brings to mind luxury in pastels—delicate pastries and champagne, 12 kinds of tea—and maybe some falconry out on the lawn. But at [The Langham Hotel in Chicago](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/chicago/2013/10/langham-new-hotel-chicago-skyscraper-mies-van-der-rohe)’s historic Mies van der Rohe skyscraper, guests will soon be able to experience an afternoon tea service for a nickel and a dime.











In honor of the hotel line’s (all-important) 149th anniversary, the Langham Pavilion lounge will serve a luxury tea service for the original 1865 price of 15 cents, once a month, all year long—a fairly incredible deal that includes sweet and savory bites by pastry chef Scott Green, champagne, and tea, all backed by live music. Here’s the kicker: Only 40 spots are available each month, and you have to follow the Langham on [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/LanghamChicago) and [Twitter](https://twitter.com/LanghamChicago) to find out when reservations are open. The next tea, on June 10, will start taking bookings today, so keep an eye on their social media feeds. And don’t forget: Pinky up.

fields.name: Laura Dannen Redman
fields.shortBio: Laura Dannen Redman is the digital deputy editor of Condé Nast Traveler.
fields.bio: Laura Dannen Redman is the digital deputy editor of *Condé Nast Traveler*. When she was three, her dad alleges she sat up in the back seat of the family station wagon, struggling against the seat belt to look out the window, and said, "I want to see the world!" Some things never change. She has a decade of international newspaper and magazine experience; most recently, she was deputy editor of *Time Out Singapore* and arts editor of *Seattle Met* magazine, where she won a National City and Regional Magazine Award (CRMA) for Multiplatform Storytelling. Laura is a Princeton grad with a master’s in journalism from Boston University’s College of Communication.

pinterest.hed: The Perfect Weekend Getaway In Chicago
pinterest.dek: The Windy City has plenty of attractions to keep you busy in the summer, including 26 miles of sandy beaches along Lake Michigan. Here’s what you need to do if you book a trip to Chicago.
pinterest.seoTitle: The Perfect Weekend Getaway In Chicago
pinterest.seoDescription: The Windy City has plenty of attractions to keep you busy in the summer, including 26 miles of sandy beaches along Lake Michigan. Here’s what you need to do if you book a trip to Chicago.
pinterest.socialTitle: The Perfect Weekend Getaway In Chicago
pinterest.socialDescription: The Windy City has plenty of attractions to keep you busy in the summer, including 26 miles of sandy beaches along Lake Michigan. Here’s what you need to do if you book a trip to Chicago.
pinterest.body:
[#image: /photos/53e2dd86c2d3f39d3610644b]|||Chicago skyline|||

**Why you should go:** For starters, there’s a sunny, 26-mile shoreline that puts the East and West Coasts to shame. Boasting a half-dozen beaches along Lake Michigan, Chicago is ideal for sun seekers who’d rather not deal with the crowds—and traffic—of Malibu or the Hamptons. Beyond the beach, there are lush urban parks, lively street festivals, free al fresco concerts, hip new restaurants, and one of the best cocktail scenes in the country. And really, those are only a few of the reasons why Chicagoans believe the Midwest is best.









[#image: /photos/53daab78dcd5888e145c4194]|||The Langham Chicago’s airy lobby boasts accents of pink—the hotel chain’s signature color. (It’s even available in a nail polish hue, for sale in the hotel’s charming gift shop). The ceiling sculpture, one of many interesting works of art collected for the hotel, was designed to reflect the flow of the Chicago River.|||

** Where to stay:**  Downtown Chicago’s newest luxury hotel is [The Langham, Chicago,](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/chicago/2013/10/langham-new-hotel-chicago-skyscraper-mies-van-der-rohe) home to one of the swankiest spas in town. It’s centrally located in Mies van der Rohe’s iconic IBM Building, and features postcard-worthy views of the Chicago River. And if you’re planning to do any shopping while in town, [The Waldorf Astoria’s](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/waldorf-astoria-chicago-chicago-illinois) beautiful, jewel-box hotel tucked into the Gold Coast offers a luxe crash pad in the heart of Chicago’s upscale retail district.



** Where to eat:**  The ultimate Chicago dining experience would be an evening-length meal at celeb chef Grant Achatz’s [Next](http://nextrestaurant.com/). The menu changes frequently, with a different theme in place every few months; but the real challenge is trying to score tickets in advance. For something slightly more low-key, head to hip Logan Square, one of the city’s best hubs for dining. Book a table at [Lula Café](http://lulacafe.com/), a farm-to-table favorite since 1999, or go for gastropub fare at [Longman & Eagle](http://longmanandeagle.com).













[#image: /photos/53e2dd87dddaa35c30f61233]|||The Violet Hour|||

** Where to drink:**  In the past few years, Chicago has become overrun with quality craft-cocktail joints, but its first remains its best: [The Violet Hour](http://theviolethour.com/), in Wicker Park, was launched by superstar bartender Toby Maloney (of NYC’s Rusty Knot and Pouring Ribbons) in 2007, and it’s still a destination. Unsurprisingly, several TVH alumni have since opened bars of their own ([Barrelhouse Flat](http://barrelhouseflat.com/), [Analogue](http://www.analoguechicago.com/), [Sable](http://sablechicago.com/)), all worth visiting for their thoughtful menus of classics old and new. If you’re confined to downtown drinking, follow the wall of skulls to underground tiki haven [Three Dots and a Dash](http://threedotschicago.com/), for legendary bartender Paul McGee’s shrine to throwback rum drinks.













[#image: /photos/53e2dd87dddaa35c30f61223]|||Millennium Park|||

** What to do:**  The best way to experience Chicago in the summertime is the [Chicago Architecture Foundation’s River Cruise](https://www.architecture.org/rivercruise), which floats along the Chicago River at a snapshot-friendly pace. (Don't worry—it’s okay if you Instagram the same view of the Willis Tower or the Marina City Buildings that everyone else does.) Summer storms (or unbearable humidity) call for ducking into the [Art Institute of Chicago](http://artic.edu/) for a few hours; book early to see the museum’s new [Magritte exhibit](http://www.artic.edu/exhibition/magritte-mystery-ordinary-1926-1938), which is sure to be a hit. The museum also offers stunning views of [Millennium Park](http://millenniumpark.com/), but if the weather’s nice, it’s best to experience the green space—home to Anish Kapoor’s iconic Cloud Gate sculpture—from the ground level. Yes, they’re some of Chicago’s most popular tourist destinations, but once you visit, you’ll see why they’re beloved by locals, too.

pinterest.hed: The Perfect New Year’s Eve in Chicago
pinterest.dek: Thanks to a thriving restaurant scene and cocktail culture, a stunning urban landscapes, and direct flights from virtually everywhere, Chicago is a great place to ring in the New Year. Here’s what to do and see.
pinterest.seoTitle: The Perfect New Year’s Eve in Chicago
pinterest.seoDescription: Thanks to a thriving restaurant scene and cocktail culture, a stunning urban landscapes, and direct flights from virtually everywhere, Chicago is a great place to ring in the New Year. Here’s what to do and see.
pinterest.socialTitle: The Perfect New Year’s Eve in Chicago
pinterest.socialDescription: Thanks to a thriving restaurant scene and cocktail culture, a stunning urban landscapes, and direct flights from virtually everywhere, Chicago is a great place to ring in the New Year. Here’s what to do and see.
pinterest.body:
[#image: /photos/53da8cabdcd5888e145bbdd8]|||Chicago's Buckingham Fountain|||





**Why You're Going** Chicago, the “City in a Garden,” offers up a striking urban skyline dotted with greenery—romantic, tree-lined sidewalks and the sprawling, verdant [Millennium Park](http://www.cityofchicago.org/city/en/depts/dca/supp_info/millennium_park.html). Unlike many other major cities, Chicago is a happening metropolis, yet there's room to breathe. Plus, as the hub for United Airlines, Chicago is reachable via direct flights from pretty much every major airport in the world. Once you've arrived, its winter-friendly public transportation system and underground pedways make for easy adventures through its neighborhoods. Throw in a thriving restaurant scene, a cosmopolitan cocktail culture, and the world’s best performing arts, and you’ve got a Midwestern mecca that’s perfect for ringing in the New Year.





[#image: /photos/53da8cab6dec627b149f2153]|||New Year's Eve tasting menu at Grace|||





**What You're Doing** Book a room at the beautiful [Waldorf Astoria Chicago](http://waldorfastoria3.hilton.com/en/hotels/illinois/waldorf-astoria-chicago-CHIWAWA/index.html), whose grand Gold Coast courtyard features heated stone pavers for a warm welcome. Plan your itinerary over an Old Fashioned in the neighborhood’s best cocktail den, [Bernard’s Bar](http://www.waldorfastoriachicagohotel.com/explore-hotel/dining/bernards-bar), which happens to be tucked away on the second floor. The city’s best shopping lies within a few blocks, but you might want to save your energy for the main event: dinner.



It’s difficult to go wrong in this foodie-friendly town, especially if you focus on the West Loop, home to the city’s hotspots. Top Chef Stephanie Izard has two restaurants within walking distance ([Girl and the Goat](http://www.girlandthegoat.com/), [Little Goat Diner](http://littlegoatchicago.com/)), Chef Paul Kahan has three ([Blackbird](http://blackbirdrestaurant.com/), [Avec](http://avecrestaurant.com/), [Publican](http://thepublicanrestaurant.com/)), restaurateur Brendan Sodikoff has a pair ([Au Cheval](http://auchevalchicago.com/), [Maude’s Liquor Bar](http://www.maudesliquorbar.com/))… and the list goes on and on. New York, eat your heart out.











New Year's Eve Tip If you’re going all out, book the tasting-menu experience at award-winning [Grace](http://www.grace-restaurant.com/), which offers two seatings (5:30 p.m., 9 p.m.) to accommodate New Year’s plans. To toast 2014 with the locals, head to [The Violet Hour](http://theviolethour.com/) in Wicker Park for some of the city’s best cocktails in a luxe, firelit lounge.

featuredEats.name: Lula Cafe
featuredEats.description: Some places exude a trendy élan by not trying too hard, and Lula Cafe is one such place. It may be Chicago's hippest kitchen, while pretending not to notice or care. What draws the neighborhood crowds to this Logan Square clubhouse is partly the cheerful, informal staff and the casual atmosphere, both of which belie the pristine food. Serving all three meals, the café reaches its culinary climax with dinner entrées like roast leg of lamb paired with sherry-braised black figs. But if you want to hunker down for the day, start with the breakfast brioche French toast, and keep on eating.
featuredEats.shortDescription: Local crowds flock to this trendy Logan Square spot for its casual atmosphere and pristine food.

featuredEats.name: Girl & The Goat
featuredEats.description: The flagship restaurant of *Top Chef* star Stephanie Izard (the first woman to win the title), this vast dinner hotspot transcends its chef's energetic personality, brimming with "fun" food divided into an easily navigable menu: Vegetable, Fish, and Meat. From there, anything goes, including the occasional Asian-influenced salad or southern-fried side. The restaurant blends its own wine, has brewed its own beer and hand-picks its own barrels of whiskey, adding a personal touch to everything it offers.
featuredEats.shortDescription: The fun menu at Stephanie Izard's hotspot is divided by type of cuisine: vegetable, meat, or fish.

featuredEats.name: Blackbird
featuredEats.description: One of the pioneering tenants of Randolph Street's now famous Restaurant Row, Blackbird is renowned chef Paul Kahan's original restaurant, which opened in 1997 as a white-tablecloth destination for power lunches and decadent dinners. Named for the French slang for Merlot, Blackbird has remained relevant for nearly two decades via stunning presentation of modern Midwestern fare, including its wow-worthy desserts.
featuredEats.shortDescription: Blackbird is one of the pioneering tenants of Randolph Street's now-famous Restaurant Row.

featuredEats.name: Avec
featuredEats.description: This tiny wine-focused restaurant opened in 2003, but its allure has never waned (warning: neither have the mobs of people trying to get in). The menu is under the new direction of chef Erling Wu-Bower, but it remains rooted in North African and Mediterranean flavors: roasted swordfish with yellow lentils, a crispy focaccia stuffed with taleggio. Let the server pick a wine for you, and don't be embarrassed to go for one under $30—bargain bottles are the specialty here.
featuredEats.cuisine: Eclectic or Global, Moroccan or North African
featuredEats.shortDescription: The allure of this wine-heavy restaurant hasn't waned in a decade (warning: neither have the crowds).

featuredPlays.name: Millennium Park
featuredPlays.description: Though it’s only been around for a decade, Millennium Park is now one of Chicago’s most popular destinations—thanks, in part, to the throngs of tourists taking selfies in the reflective surface of Anish Kapoor’s Cloud Gate (better known as The Bean). But that’s not the only reason to visit: The nearly 25-acre park is also home to the Frank Gehry-designed Jay Pritzker Pavilion (which hosts concerts), public-art projects, and an ice-skating rink in the winter. The Nichols Bridgeway also connects the space to the Art Institute of Chicago and Grant Park, just a ways down Michigan Avenue. The dramatic 15-foot-high Shoulder Hedge that separates the Lurie Garden from the rest of the park was inspired by Carl Sandburg’s poem “Chicago,” in which he refers to the town as “the City of Big Shoulders.”

address.street: Enter at E. Washington St. and N. Michigan Ave.

featuredPlays.shortDescription: Come here to take a selfie in front of Anish Kapoor’s Cloud Gate (better known as The Bean).

featuredPlays.name: The Second City
featuredPlays.description: The Second City is the most famous of Chicago's improv theaters, and rightfully so: It's churned out the likes of John Belushi, Dan Aykroyd, Tina Fey, and Amy Poehler, and you're likely to get a preview of future stars of *Saturday Night Live* on any given night. With long-running shows on the main Resident Stage and one-off improv nights and revues at the adjoining UP Comedy Club, there's something worth seeing any night of the week, and dinner packages are available at neighborhood restaurants.
featuredPlays.shortDescription: The Second City is Chicago's most famous improv theater, with alumni like Tina Fey and Amy Poehler.

featuredPlays.description: Perhaps best known for appearing in the opening credits of the sitcom *Perfect Strangers,*this venue in the Loop has quite a storied past. It originally opened in 1921 as a movie theater, and over the years attracted celebrities like Orson Welles, Ronald Reagan, and the Three Stooges. Now, it plays host to all manner of music, comedy, and theatrical performances.
featuredPlays.shortDescription: Chicago's most iconic theater hosts all manner of live music, comedy, and theater performances.
featuredPlays.name: The Chicago Theatre

featuredPlays.description: The century-old, ivy-lined field sits in the middle of the city, providing the sort of intimate baseball experience (and skyline views) that doesn't exist at newer ballparks. Plus, you'll see the city's die-hard sports culture on display: The Cubs haven't won a World Series since 1908, but fans pack the stadium for nearly every home game, even on weekday afternoons.
featuredPlays.shortDescription: The century-old field provides the sort of intimate experience that doesn't exist at newer ballparks.
featuredPlays.name: Wrigley Field

contributorsAuthor.shortBio: Hanya Yanagihara is the former editor-at-large at *Conde Nast Traveler.*
contributorsAuthor.bio: Hanya Yanagihara is the former editor-at-large at *Conde Nast Traveler* and the author of the novels *The People in the Trees* and *A Little Life* (March 2015). She is currently deputy editor of T magazine.

contributorsAuthor.name: Lauren Kilberg
contributorsAuthor.shortBio: Collector of maps, passport stamps, and freckles.
contributorsAuthor.bio: Lauren Kilberg is a freelance writer and blogger residing in Chicago. Her travels have found her camping near the Pakistani border of India, conquering volcanoes in the Philippines and being humbled in Haiti. She spent two years living and working in South Korea before repatriating to the United States, but not before taking the six-month scenic route home via a backpacking trip from Indonesia to India. In short, she's a collector of maps, passport stamps, and freckles.

shop.hed: A Shopping Guide to Chicago's Wicker Park Area
shop.dek: Chicago's shopping scene is more than a single magnificent mile. The different nooks and neighborhoods scattered throughout the city provide endless options for emptying your wallet while filling your shopping bags. If you're looking for a high concentration of a variety of shops, head to the triple-threat area of Wicker Park/Bucktown/Ukrainian Village.
shop.body:
[#image: /photos/54944208d8a6b59e539bc87f]||||||





##Home Decor

[Antique Taco](http://www.antiquetaco.com/old-stuff/) 

At this taqueria and antique shop hybrid you can order a pork carnitas taco, pop open a cerveza, and peruse vintage decor. *(1360 N. Milwaukee Avenue)*

[Sprout Home](http://www.sprouthome.com) 

This is your one-stop shop for indoor foliage. The aptly-named Sprout specializes in plants, planters and vases, but carries a variety of other home decor and accessories. *(745 N. Damen Avenue)*

[Province](http://www.provincejournal.com)  

Located in the iconic Flat Iron Arts Building, this eclectic and curated home decor store (and blog) sells everything from salvaged pottery and oil paintings to natural science specimens and succulents. *(1579 N. Milwaukee Avenue #315)*



##Apparel

[P. 45](http://www.p45.com) 

A well-curated boutique featuring designer (both up-and-coming and well known) apparel. P.45 has you covered from head to toe with sunglasses, handbags, clothing, and shoes. *(1643 N. Damen Avenue Chicago)*

[The Silver Room](http://thesilverroom.com) 

The Silver Room isn't merely located in Wicker Park, it's rooted in the community there. Just a few of the titles this shop boasts include clothing boutique, event space, gallery, and juice bar. *(1442 N. Milwaukee Avenue)*

[Marc by Marc Jacobs](http://www.marcjacobs.com/stores/#!/store/291057) 

One of the big names to call this neighborhood home, Marc by Marc Jacobs carries everything you'd expect from the renowned designer. *(1714 North Damen Avenue)*


##Everything Else

[Stitch](http://www.stitchchicago.com/) 

This Wicker Park/Bucktown institution has been selling its wares for the past 16 years. Shop here for designer men's, women's, and children's apparel, as well as accessories, furniture, and gifts. *(1937 N. Damen Avenue)*

[Myopic Books](http://www.myopicbookstore.com/)  

You can't venture into the Wicker Park area and not visit the much-loved Myopic Books. This neighborhood icon houses more then 80,000 volumes. It also plays host to concerts and a poetry series. *(1564 N. Milwaukee Avenue)*


[RR#1](http://www.rr1chicago.com) 

A self-described "old fashioned shop for modern goods," RR#1 in Ukrainian Village is where you head for a gift for that person in your life who has everything. Housed in a 1930s pharmacy, the shop sells candles, cards, jewelry, toys and so much more. *(814 N. Ashland Avenue)*

shop.hed: We Love These Cool Sneakers, Designed By Street Artists Across the World
shop.dek: Why wear shoes when you can wear a piece of art? These awesome kicks made by Chicago-based "shoe lab" BucketFeet have been designed by local artists around the world.
shop.seoTitle: We Love These Cool Sneakers, Designed By Street Artists Across the World
shop.seoDescription: Why wear shoes when you can wear a piece of art? These awesome kicks made by Chicago-based "shoe lab" BucketFeet have been designed by local artists around the world.
shop.socialTitle: We Love These Cool Sneakers, Designed By Street Artists Across the World
shop.socialDescription: Why wear shoes when you can wear a piece of art? These awesome kicks made by Chicago-based "shoe lab" BucketFeet have been designed by local artists around the world.
shop.body:
[#image: /photos/53da85b8dcd5888e145b9999]||||||

When you wear a pair of [BucketFeet](http://www.bucketfeet.com/), you're not just wearing a pair of shoes—you're wearing a piece of art. That's according to creators Aaron Firestein and Raaja Nemani, the masterminds behind this Chicago-based "shoe lab," that has commissioned more than 100 artists from across 30 countries to design limited-edition sneakers—dubbed BucketFeet.





By paying global artists—many of whom are unknown street artists—an initial fee for their shoe design, plus a commission from each $68 shoe sale, BucketFeet is able to support art across the world. Each shoebox comes with a card describing the artist's inspiration, where they're from, a picture of their artwork, and contact details. "Without the support I get from art, the balance, I'd be another lost number, [taking] drugs, who knows?" [said Leandro Tick](http://vimeo.com/36518894), the Brazilian favela artist, who designed BucketFeet's '[Bosque](http://blog.bucketfeet.com/2012/02/10/new-shoe-release-bosque-by-tick-designed-in-brazil/)' shoes.



It's also a way for artists to express themselves and connect with worldwide audiences. "If I speak or write Japanese, you might not understand me," said graffiti artist Suiko, from Hiroshima, Japan. Suiko designed BucketFeet's '[Earth](http://www.bucketfeet.com/index.php/women/earth-women.html)' sneaker, which uses a reinterpretation of traditional Chinese characters and Japanese calligraphy and woodblock prints. "Art, it's visual language."





[#image: /photos/53da85b86dec627b149efdc7]|||Left: Jayson Atienza, Right: Earth|||

Similarly, artist Jayson Atienza of New Jersey, used his [eponymous shoe](http://www.bucketfeet.com/index.php/men/jayson-atienza-men.html) as a canvas to express his colorful upbringing in Jersey City: "You're immersed in hip-hop, and graffiti, and break dancing," said the artist.



The latest round of BucketFeet models will be released [online](http://www.bucketfeet.com/) on Cyber Monday, December 2.











**More on fashion and travel:**







[Are These The World's Comfiest Travel Shoes?](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/07/summer-travel-footwear-shoes-lookmybabouchr)







[When in London, Buy Shoes](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/07/sophia-webster-shoe-shopping-london)







[Style Pick: Bespoke Vara Shoes from Salvatore Ferragamo](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/05/style-pick-ferragamo-customizable-travel-shoes)

[#image: /photos/53e2ff4cdddaa35c30f690cc]||||||

Hunting season is now in full swing at [Kane County Flea Market](http://www.kanecountyfleamarket.com), located about an hour west of Chicago in St. Charles, Illinois, where antique oddities have been served up for more than four decades. And while the recent upsurge in vintage treasure-hunter shows might make it seem like everybody with a pulse (and cable television) has suddenly become an expert picker, local flea market veteran Rick Lidinsky offers a few helpful hints to help ensure you come home with some great one-of-a-kind finds.










##### School Yourself Before You Go


Lidinsky, a Chicago-based dealer who sells vintage eyewear and '50s rhinestone-encrusted Western stagewear at markets around the country, encourages shoppers to price-check want-list items ahead of time on eBay. “It’s great for researching an item, but eBay can’t compare to getting to touch the object and see firsthand whether it has any flaws.”










##### At the Show


Like most flea markets, negotiating is encouraged at Kane County—but there are rules. “Don’t try to get a discount on a $10 item,” Lidinsky says. Instead, you’ll have better luck grouping together several items and then negotiating a discount on the lot. And bring cash. “You might get a better price because credit cards charge vendors for every transaction.” Heavier finds—like mid-century furniture, which the market is known for—are also ripe for bargaining: Vendors would rather sell at a discount than lug bulky items back home at the end of the day. Finally, timing is key: Lidinski says arrive early for the best selection, or arrive late for the best bargains.










##### Look Closely


“Condition is the most important thing,” Lidinsky says. While he says that Kane County’s dealers are pretty educated about their wares, it’s ultimately the buyer’s responsibility to identify flaws before purchasing. “Don’t get too caught up in the romance of your find that you forget to ask yourself things like: Are these chairs sturdy? Does this clothing have holes in it? Or did someone do a lousy restoration job on this furniture and ruin it?” Sometimes, of course, Lidinsky admits, minor flaws just add character.










##### One Last Tip


“Great things sell immediately; don’t let a great thing slip though your fingers,” Lidinsky says. “If it moves you, if there’s rapture, if your heart’s working faster than your mind and you have the money in your pocket…buy it!”













[#image: /photos/53e2ff4adddaa35c30f690ba]||||||

[#image: /photos/53e2ff4fdddaa35c30f690de]||||||

[#image: /photos/53e2ff4ac2d3f39d3610e586]||||||

[#image: /photos/53e2ff4ac2d3f39d3610e576]||||||

[#image: /photos/53e2ff4ac2d3f39d3610e588]||||||

[#image: /photos/53e2ff4ac2d3f39d3610e58a]||||||

[#image: /photos/53e2ff4ec2d3f39d3610e5b6]||||||







 [The Kane County Flea Market](http://www.kanecountyfleamarket.com) takes place July 6–7, August 3–4, Aug 31–Sept 1, October 5–6, November 2–3, and Nov 30–Dec 1._ Kane County Fairgrounds, 525 S Randall Rd, St. Charles, IL; (630-377-2252); $5 admission_





Why go/what you'll see: The market’s well known for affordable vintage furniture, from atomic '50s dinettes to sophisticated '60s Danish modern dressers or credenzas. Also on offer are collectible barware, artwork, jewelry, and clothing, plus the occasional upcycled creation and other surprises.



How to get there: Driving, take I-290 West, exiting west at Route 64 (North Avenue). Turn left (south) on Randall Road, and the fairgrounds will be on your right. Parking is free.



Must-eat place: If all that haggling has worked up an appetite, check out the Wisconsin Cheese Curds food truck on site for piping hot, lightly battered, cheesy bite-size snacks. Brats and pizza are also for sale on the fairgrounds, but for something more substantial, head to [Preservation Bread & Wine](http://preservationbreadandwine.com/) (513 S Third St) in nearby Geneva to rejuvenate with modern American fare such as a wild mushroom tart or smoked trout rillette.



Don’t forget: Wear comfy shoes and don’t leave behind your sunscreen, bottled water, a sturdy canvas tote and—to bolster your bargaining position—cash money. The market is not easily accessible via public transit. But if you score big, you’ll need a car anyway.



Make a weekend of it: Extend your appreciation of history from the antiques at the flea market to Geneva’s historic town center. The picturesque Fox River runs right through town, drawing avid cyclists to its Fox River trail.









 Photographs by Martina Sheehan

eat.hed: The Best Airport Restaurant in the U.S. Is...
eat.dek: Our experts agree: Rick Bayless, who brought high Mexican to an American audience, has the best airport restaurant in the U.S.
eat.seoTitle: The Best Airport Restaurant in the U.S.
eat.socialTitle: The Best Airport Restaurant in the U.S.
eat.body:
[#image: /photos/5420a22b17e4b1f634ef187a]||||||





##Tortas Frontera by Rick Bayless, at Chicago O'Hare


Our experts agree: Rick Bayless, who brought high Mexican to an American audience, has the best airport restaurant in the country. Chef Anita Lo of N.Y.C.’s Annisa says __Tortas Frontera__ “is one of a few that actually deliver and live up to the chef’s name.” Michael Chernow of N.Y.C.’s Meatball Shop says it’s “the best airport food I’ve had to date,” and chef Jonathan Waxman deems it “really special.” What to order? Daniel Boulud likes “the braised short rib tortas à la plancha,” Chernow gets the “eggs and rajas torta or smoked pork mollete,” and Lo goes for the beer-braised short rib torta: “It comes with these tangy pickled jalapeños, cheese, beans, and cilantro.” Chef Grant Achatz says save time for a Deal-Breaker margarita. *Chicago O’Hare Terminal 1, Gate B11; Terminal 3, Gate K4; and Terminal 5, Gate M12*

Read on for the full list of [Top Airport Food Around the World](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-09-23/the-best-airport-food-in-the-world).
