fields.name: CNTraveler.com
fields.shortBio: Food and fashion, design and destinations, tips and tricks. Global inspiration from Condé Nast Traveler.
fields.bio: Food and fashion, design and destinations, tips and tricks. Global inspiration from Condé Nast Traveler.

eat.dek: Travelers love to eat. That's why, every year in our Readers' Choice Survey, we ask our readers to rate the U.S. cities that have the best restaurants. This year, we were surprised by some of the winners. We think you will be too.
eat.hed: The Best American Cities for Foodies

items.title: 19. San Diego
items.caption: Our Top 20 list starts off with a tie between the East and West Coasts. Representing the west, we have san Diego, where the growing food scene is one of the hottest in Southern California. Get your fill of local seafood at La Jolla mainstay [George’s at the Cove](http://www.georgesatthecove.com/), or nab a seat at [Sushi Ota’s](http://otasushi.com/wp/) sushi bar. Chef Hanis Cavin’s [Carnitas’ Snack Shack](http://carnitassnackshack.com/) (pictured), a favorite newcomer, is your best bet for gourmet-casual fare_. —Valentina Silva_

items.title: 19. Portland, ME
items.caption: Just as the city of Portland has transformed itself from scruffy to sophisticated, so too has its cuisine—which explains why it finds itself on our Top 20 list, tied with San Diego. Yes, there’s still ample opportunity to chow down on a fresh lobster roll by the water at old-school institutions like [DiMillo’s](http://www.dimillos.com/), but bolder seafood options await around every corner. Sam Hayward’s [Fore Street](http://www.forestreet.biz) is the restaurant that kicked off Portland’s food revolution nearly 20 years ago and continues to be one of its great innovators with a daily changing menu of locally sourced items, prepared rustic-style in a wood-burning oven. While (relative) newcomers like [Eventide Oyster Co](http://www.eventideoysterco.com/). (pictured), a tribute to the old-fashioned raw bar, and the [Miyake](http://www.miyakerestaurants.com/home/) family of Japan-meets-Maine eateries are a testament to the city’s increasingly adventurous palate._ —Jennifer M. Wood_

items.title: 18. Telluride, CO
items.caption: Stunning mountain scenery, [exclusive ski resort](http://www.cntraveler.com/ski-areas/2013/12/best-ski-resorts-north-america_slideshow_item20_21), sophisticated seclusion—this historic hamlet wrapped in 14,000-foot peaks has it all while retaining just enough of its mining-boomtown roots to keep it rowdy. Start your feast with a late lunch at [Bon Vivant](http://www.telluride.com/bon-vivant), an alfresco perch elevating French comfort food to match the San Juan views; pair a sharp Alsace Pino Gris with the gruyere-smothered onion soup dunked with a slow-braised short rib. The ski slopes tumble into town where the après scene stays cool at [There](http://www.therebars.com) by Nobu alum Andrew Tyler. The ramshackle-hip hut filled with mountain bric-a-brac combines craft cocktails and choice Colorado-Asian fusion small plates like crispy duck breast steamed buns and rare Wagyu steak served with four dipping sauces. Dinner is served at [221 South Oak](http://www.221southoak.com) where _Top Chef_ alum Eliza Gavin’s locally sourced game sausages and extensive wine list are served in a cozy restored Victorian home. Unruly dudes and famous faces alike have sidled up to the historic [New Sheridan Bar](http://www.newsheridan.com) since 1895, and these days the hotel preserving it is a [perennial Readers’ Choice](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/new-sheridan-hotel-telluride-telluride-colorado) fave. All the better, then, to wrap your night here with a pint [Telluride Brewing’s](http://www.telluridebrewingco.com) Face-Down Brown Ale, a Great American Beer Festival gold-medal brew._ —Alex Pasquariello_

items.title: 17. Naples, FL
items.caption: Given its tropical climate and Gulf of Mexico perch, you’re going to get at least one seafood option at almost any restaurant you visit in Naples. And if that’s why you’re here, the boat-to-belly offerings at [Truluck’s](http://trulucks.com/pages/naples-florida)—including their famous stone crabs—are some of the area’s freshest. But Naples is a cosmopolitan city, and as such has a vast number of impressive international eats. For French Provencal, there’s Claudio Scaduto’s [Côte d’Azur](http://www.cotedazurrestaurant.com/); for Spanish tapas off-the-beaten path, try [IM Tapas](http://imtapas.com). [Caffe dell’Amore](http://www.caffedellamore.com/) is a top choice for Italian, while [Inca’s Kitchen](http://incaskitchens.com/) serves up authentic Peruvian dishes like lomo saltado (sautéed beef loin) in a comfortable setting. If you can’t choose just one, [Mereday’s](http://www.meredaysnaples.com) offers an eclectic mix of flavors from around the world (think mussels with Indian madras curry and coconut milk)._ —Jennifer M. Wood_

items.title: 16. Austin, TX
items.caption: Austin has never been short on good food (take, for example, the piled-high pulled pork at [Franklin](https://franklinbarbecue.com/menu/)). But these days, chefs are adding all sorts of culinary twists to the Texas capital. At his new [namesake restaurant](http://quiaustin.com/) (pictured) Paul Qui—of [East Side King](https://www.facebook.com/EastSideKingATX) clout—offers Southwestern staples like short ribs covered in Thai herbs, followed by a decadent cheddar cheese ice cream for dessert. And the East Austin food truck scene deserves a Zagat guide unto itself. _—Laura Carroll_

items.title: 15. Savannah, GA
items.caption: Now that Paula Deen’s waterfront hub Uncle Bubba’s Oyster House is closed, what, pray tell, will anyone talk about? How about the arrival of James Beard Award winner and _Top Chef_ judge Hugh Acheson, who makes his Savannah debut in May with Italian restaurant [Florence](http://eater.com/archives/2013/08/09/hugh-achesons-the-florence-to-open-in-savannah-2014.php)? Or the continued excellence of [The Olde Pink House](http://www.plantersinnsavannah.com/the-olde-pink-house/) (pictured), where diners can enjoy a juicy bourbon-molasses grilled pork tenderloin with collard greens and sweet potatoes in an 18th-century mansion, followed by a beer downstairs in a bar that seems plucked from the colonial era? Or how about the fact that Savannah was ranked [third-friendliest city in the U.S.](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/07/travel-us-cities-charleston-newark-branson-friendly-unfriendly) by our readers? Clearly, it seems there’s plenty to keep travelers talking about this southern city. _—Laura Dannen Redman_

items.title: 14. Newport, RI
items.caption: Though there are fish shacks aplenty in this tony New England city—[Flo’s Clam Shack](http://www.flosclamshacks.com/flo-s-newport.html) is a 78-year-old institution—Newport’s most noteworthy eateries offer more upscale takes on seafood in more formal settings. Which makes sense, given Newport’s island location and former life as a Gilded Age playground. At [Castle Hill Inn Dining Room](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/castle-hill-inn-resort-newport-newport-united-states) overlooking Narragansett Bay, chef Karsten Hart emphasizes local ingredients in dishes like broiled cod with smoked seaweed butter. At [Spiced Pear](http://www.thechanler.com/dining/dinner/), fine diners line up for the New England Tasting Menu, which—if you’re lucky—will include chilled local oysters with horseradish bacon sorbet._ —Jennifer M. Wood_

items.title: 13. Seattle
items.caption: Yes, Seattle has (excellent) coffee and salmon, and the fishmongers will toss the fresh catch of the day for your amusement in [Pike Place Market](http://www.pikeplacemarket.org/), but the city is so much more than its stereotypes. Chefs walk the walk here, showing true dedication to local ingredients and innovation, from James Beard Award nominee Renee Erickson’s soul-cleansing oysters at [The Walrus and the Carpenter](http://thewalrusbar.com/) to the lamb popsicles at [Shanik](http://shanikrestaurant.com/) (pictured), sister restaurant to the famed Vancouver, B.C., Indian eatery Vij’s. Ethan Stowell is another of Seattle's James Beard Award nominees, and his family-style Italian Sunday dinners at [Tavolàta](http://www.ethanstowellrestaurants.com/locations/tavolata/) (which, dare we say it, rival our grandmother’s) are not to be missed._—Laura Dannen Redman_

items.title: 12. Las Vegas
items.caption:
Headliners of the stage aren't the only big names in Vegas. In recent years, celebrity chefs have set up their own culinary residencies in Sin City's biggest casino hotels. The star-studded list includes Michelin-­starred French chefs like Joel Robuchon at MGM Grand and Pierre Gagnaire at the Mandarin Oriental, while Jose Andres experiments with Mexican and Chinese cuisine side by side (not fused together) at China Poblano at The Cosmopolitan (pictured). For sushi lovers, chef Nobu Matsuhisa opened his first Nobu hotel at Caesars Palace, serving green tea waffles and specialty bento boxes through room service.





And then there are the TV chefs: Bobby Flay, Gordon Ramsay, Tom Colicchio, Buddy V a.k.a. The Cake Boss, and Giada de Laurentiis, who will serve simple Italian plates at her first­ever restaurant at The Cromwell, opening next month.  As for the answer to the age­old Vegas question, “Where’s the best steakhouse?,” there’s no right or wrong choice nowadays, thanks to Wolfgang Puck’s CUT, Mario Batali’s Carnevino, Charlie Palmer Steak, Steve Wynn’s SW Steak, and NYC’s Old Homestead. _—Juliana Shallcross_

items.title: 11. Aspen
items.caption: America’s premier winter playground adds another celeb-chef notch to its belt this spring with the opening of [David Burke Kitchen](http://www.davidburkekitchenaspen.com). Executive chef Matt O’Neill (poached from The Little Nell) will lend the place his locavore cred—don't miss the local elk, lamb and beef that will be prepared in a custom dry aging room. For seafood, hit Iron Chef [Nobu Matsuhisa’s](http://www.matsuhisaaspen.com) sushi outpost, an eternally a hot table for A-listers and X-Gamers alike. Aspen’s après scene isn't just about food though; locally made beers add to the city's culinary cred. Toast a powder day at [Aspen Brewing Company’s Tasting Room](http://aspenbrewingcompany.com/tag/beer-tasting-room/" t "_blank) over pints of Independence Pass Ale, Pyramid Peak Porter and Conundrum Red Ale. A stylish speakeasy-slash-restaurant in the historic wheeler Opera House, [Justice Snow’s](http://justicesnows.com) is the spot to sample locally distilled spirits in craft cocktails by “Lead Libation Liaison” Joshua-Peter Smith including a Chepita cobbler with [Woody Creek Colorado Potato Vodka](http://www.woodycreekdistillers.com/), Carlson Plum Wine, honey, a muddled peach, cherries and bit of tarragon shaken with crushed ice._ —Alex Pasquariello_

items.title: 10. Boston
items.caption: While history may associate Boston dining with such old-school (and often bland) dishes as brown bread, baked beans, and clam chowder, there’s been a changing of the guards in recent years. Chefs who have spent years studying under the city’s most notable cooks are breaking out and opening up their own joints, which couple upscale eats with laidback vibes. In the South End, [Merrill & Co.](http://www.merrillandcoboston.com/) promotes sharing plates of fried oysters in a squid ink aioli, cast iron mussels with red curry and ginger, and pork belly with baby carrots and za’atar. In Harvard Square, [Alden & Harlow](http://aldenharlow.com/) (pictured) does the gastropub trend proud with a 'secret' burger that is packing crowds in. While in Downtown Crossing, [The Merchant](http://www.themerchantboston.com) is putting a New England spin on the American brasserie, serving up everything from green curry mussels to fish and chips into the wee hours of the morning. _—Jennifer M. Wood_

items.title: 9. Healdsburg, CA
items.caption: Ask any twenty- or thirty-something in the Bay Area to name their favorite city in California wine country, and chances are you’ll hear [Healdsburg](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/12/healdsburg-sonoma-county-day-trip-san-francisco)’s name. Like the locals, the food scene is friendly and welcoming, with an impressive range of creative talent for such a small place. [Chalkboard](http://chalkboardhealdsburg.com/) has a contemporary vibe and house-made pastas with accents like duck fat breadcrumbs. And [SHED Café](http://healdsburgshed.com/eat/shed-cafe/) (pictured) serves delightfully simple and seasonal brunches in an airy, indoor-outdoor setting. _—Stacy Adimando_

items.title: 8. Santa Fe
items.caption: An introduction to New Mexican cuisine usually starts with a declaration of allegiance: green chile or red chile? Start by sampling both at [The Shed](http://www.sfshed.com/home.html), a James Beard Award–winning restaurant that’s been managed by the same family since 1953, and serves some of the city’s best chicken enchiladas, wrapped in blue corn tortillas and smothered in red and green chile sauce. But the Santa Fe experience has grown beyond the chile war to embrace fusion fare: Mark Kiffin’s [Compound](http://www.compoundrestaurant.com/) (pictured) blends Southwestern and Mediterranean flavors, while [Restaurant Martín](http://restaurantmartin.com/)** **dishes out 'progressive American cuisine'—Southwestern and Asian influences with French technique._ —Laura Dannen Redman_

items.title: 7. Carmel-by-the-Sea, CA
items.caption: This coast city's quaint downtown area is a perfectly walkable size, which means you can cover a lot of ground (and some notable restaurant newcomers) in just one weekend. [Mundaka](http://www.mundakacarmel.com/), a Spanish tapas bar, has a rotating paella of the day and a new, next-door café pouring Ritual coffee. The attentive staff at Akaoni (24381 San Juan Rd, 831-620-1516) serves top-quality, traditional sushi, and [La Bicycletta](http://www.labicycletterestaurant.com/) spins out inventive thin crust pizzas with combos like butternut squash and speck. Some say the three are among the best spots to dine in all of Monterey County. _—Stacy Adimando_

items.title: 6. Chicago
items.caption: The Second City’s food scene has never been hotter, thanks to a healthy ratio of stalwart restaurateurs—notably [Paul Kahan](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/chicago/2013/07/chef-paul-kahan-best-restaurants-chicago-071213) (posh Italian spot [Nico Osteria](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/02/nico-osteria-italian-restaurant-chicago) (pictured) is his newest; perennial New American favorite [Blackbird](http://blackbirdrestaurant.com/) is his calling card) and [Brendan Sodikoff](http://www.hogsalt.com/) (High Five Ramen opens in May; flattop burger joint [Au Cheval](http://auchevalchicago.com/) is the favorite)—and a smattering of ethnic eateries reflecting the city’s diversity. In this town, to-die-for taquerias like [L’Patron](https://www.facebook.com/LPATRONTACOS) are just as popular as molecular-gastronomic mainstays like [Next](https://www.nextrestaurant.com). _—Lauren Viera_

items.title: 5. New Orleans
items.caption: This food-obsessed city is constantly redefining its local flavor, perfecting [beignets](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/04/best-desserts-by-region_slideshow_BEIGNETS_4) and gumbo while experimenting with the latest from nearby farms. New French Quarter restaurant Eat serves comfort food—chicken and dumplings, red beans and rice, fried green tomatoes—with the freshest ingredients; while Isaac Toups proves he's a master of Gulf shrimp, dirty rice and pork skin cracklins at [Toup's Meatery](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/01/best-pho-new-orleans-louisiana). Pork paradise [Cochon](http://www.cochonrestaurant.com/) (pictured) delivers traditional Cajun fare in a renovated warehouse in the Lower Garden District. And we’ll follow creative Chef Ian Schnoebelen from fine-dining restaurant Iris, which (sadly) closes in May, to his Italian-inspired [Mariza](http://marizaneworleans.com/) in the Bywater._ —Laura Dannen Redman_

items.title: 4. Charleston, SC
items.caption: Our readers' [favorite city in America](http://www.cntraveler.com/readers-choice-awards/united-states/best-cities-america_slideshow_item9_10) (and the one they also voted [the friendliest](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/07/travel-us-cities-charleston-newark-branson-friendly-unfriendly)) has gone way beyond standard-issue Southern in recent years, with restaurant creativity to rival much larger cities’ and, in the form of [a local edition of the food blog Eater](http://charleston.eater.com/), the discriminating diners that go with it. New restaurants like [The Ordinary](http://eattheordinary.com/) (pictured)—where local oysters are shucked inside a former bank vault—and [Xiao Bao Biscuit](http://xiaobaobiscuit.com/)—where Lowcountry riffs make Asian recipes sing—prove that the trendsetting [Husk](http://www.huskrestaurant.com/home/)—while still a winner—is far from the only game in this electric eating town._ —Paul Brady_

items.title: 3. San Francisco
items.caption: There’s no doubt SF has earned its reputation as one of the [top food cities](http://www.cntraveler.com/food/2013/07/best-new-restaurants-2013/san-francisco) in the U.S., thanks to culinary destinatons like the 18-course seasonal-fare spot [Saison](http://saisonsf.com/) (which started out as a pop-up) and off-duty-chefs' favorite [Rich Table](http://richtablesf.com/). But to experience the rustic, farm-to-table dining that helped put it on the map, have lunch at [Delfina Pizzeria](http://www.delfinasf.com/). Start with young fried favas or Sonoma-derived duck conserva with giardiniera, and don’t miss the housemade fennel sausage pie, which comes out perfectly charred and bubbly. Speaking of pie, head to the unfussy corner spot [Mission Pie](http://missionpie.com/) (pictured) for dessert. Plop down with a rhubarb-filled slice and do an hour of people watching among the hipster patrons. _—Stacy Adimando_

items.title: 2. Napa
items.caption: It wasn’t always a foodie destination, but locals will tell you the food scene across Napa Valley (which is loosely collected into a "city" for our Readers' Choice Survey) is improving every day. Of course, it started with a bang, thanks to Thomas Keller's [French Laundry](http://www.frenchlaundry.com/). And now, there's plenty more to taste. To experience a new world example, eat at the bar at [Goose and Gander](http://www.goosegander.com/) (pictured). The dim-lit pub-like interior is a fun contrast to the bright, fresh food and exquisite seasonal cocktail list by Scott Beattie. Don’t miss out on the more classic fare, like [Model Bakery](http://www.themodelbakery.com/)’s light as air English muffins, a dream come true when slathered with butter. _—Stacy Adimando_

items.title: 1. New York City
items.caption:
It's no surprise that New York landed in the No. 1 spot on our readers' list of America's top food cities. This is, after all, a city of culinary experts and of culinary upstarts. It's the foodie mecca where other chefs come to learn to be chefs, and where regular citizens learn to be food critics. This is where [David Chang](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2012/03/lucky-peach-david-chang-guide-to-international-restaurants), April Bloomfield, [Daniel Boulud](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/06/travel-habits-routine-chef-daniel-boulud-060213), Wylie Dufresne, [Bill Telepan](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/02/chef-bill-telepan-tapas-nyc-restaurants), [Tom Colicchio](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/12/celebrity-christmas-gift-ideas), and [Marcus Samuelsson](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2012/06/chef-marcus-samuelsson-food-predictions-afghani-cuisine) ply their trades. This is where you can eat burgers at Shake Shack, indulge in authentic [curry in Queens](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/03/chef-eli-sussman-queens-curry-bun-ker), and throw back oysters and cocktails at [Maison Premiere](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/02/hurricane-brooklyn-cocktail-bar-maison-premiere). But it's not all about famous chefs in this town—it's about authentic international cuisine and small mom-and-pop kitchens too. Oh, and [desserts](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/04/best-desserts-by-region_slideshow_BLACK-AND-WHITE-COOKIES_5). It's definitely about [dessert](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/new-york/2013/05/jacques-torres-new-york-chocolate-factory-tour). After all, this is the town where the cronut was created. _—Billie Cohen


_

fields.title: 19. Portland, ME
fields.caption: Just as the city of Portland has transformed itself from scruffy to sophisticated, so too has its cuisine—which explains why it finds itself on our Top 20 list, tied with San Diego. Yes, there’s still ample opportunity to chow down on a fresh lobster roll by the water at old-school institutions like [DiMillo’s](http://www.dimillos.com/), but bolder seafood options await around every corner. Sam Hayward’s [Fore Street](http://www.forestreet.biz) is the restaurant that kicked off Portland’s food revolution nearly 20 years ago and continues to be one of its great innovators with a daily changing menu of locally sourced items, prepared rustic-style in a wood-burning oven. While (relative) newcomers like [Eventide Oyster Co](http://www.eventideoysterco.com/). (pictured), a tribute to the old-fashioned raw bar, and the [Miyake](http://www.miyakerestaurants.com/home/) family of Japan-meets-Maine eateries are a testament to the city’s increasingly adventurous palate._ —Jennifer M. Wood_

eat.hed: Five Places to Get a Great Slice of Pizza in Chicago. Yes, We Said Slice.
eat.dek: Five great places to get a slice of pizza in Chicago—Jimmy's Pizza Café, Dante's Pizzeria, Café Luigi, Armitage Pizza, and D'amato's Bakery—for those times deep dish just won't do.
eat.seoTitle: Five Places to Get a Great Slice of Pizza in Chicago. Yes, We Said Slice.
eat.seoDescription: Five great places to get a slice of pizza in Chicago—Jimmy's Pizza Café, Dante's Pizzeria, Café Luigi, Armitage Pizza, and D'amato's Bakery—for those times deep dish just won't do.
eat.socialTitle: Five Places to Get a Great Slice of Pizza in Chicago. Yes, We Said Slice.
eat.socialDescription: Five great places to get a slice of pizza in Chicago—Jimmy's Pizza Café, Dante's Pizzeria, Café Luigi, Armitage Pizza, and D'amato's Bakery—for those times deep dish just won't do.
eat.body:
[#image: /photos/53daab5c6dec627b149fa5ba]|||Dante's Inferno Pie|||

It used to be next to impossible to find a good slice of thin-crust pizza in the city where deep-dish long reigned supreme. But no more. These five spots will satisfy your slice craving, no knife and fork required.





**Jimmy’s Pizza Café** Jimmy Kang opened this Lincoln Square joint because he likes to work with dough, and his crispy Neapolitan crusts prove he’s got skills. Try Jimmy’s Signature White Pizza, which starts with olive oil brushed on that killer crust before it’s topped with garlic, mozzarella, and ricotta. Kang also works his magic with garlic knots and beignets (strange, but—trust us—they’re awesome). _5159 N Lincoln Ave; 773-293-6992_











**[Café Luigi](http://www.cafeluigipizza.com)** The original, namesake owner of this Lincoln Park pizzeria came to Chicago by way of Brooklyn before heading to warmer temps down South. But he left the current proprietors his recipes for classic, New York-style pizza, calzones, and sausage rolls, along with a customer base heavy on East Coast expats. _2548 N Clark St, 773-404-0200_







**[Dante’s Pizzeria](http://www.dantespizzeriachicago.com)** Craving heat? Try a slice of the Inferno Specialty Pie, topped with poblano, banana, and jalapeno peppers, plus pepperoni, giardiniera, bacon, garlic, sausage, and red onion. Slices here are mega-sized; order one to start, even if you’ve got big eyes. _3028 W Armitage Ave; 773-342-0002_







**Armitage Pizza** James Spillane, the mastermind who gave West Town’s Coalfire cred for churning out some of the bubbliest, perfectly charred thin-crust pies in the city, now runs this no-frills, one-man shop. Slices of what he calls Neapolitan-American pizza bring in a steady stream of loyal fans who appreciate Spillane’s perfect sauce-to-cheese ratio. _711 W Armitage Ave; 312-867-9111_











**D’amato’s Bakery** Okay, so you won't find traditional Neapolitan thin-crust at this Italian bakery that’s been a city staple for more than 40 years. But it’d be a disservice to pizza lovers to omit the doughy, Sicilian-style squares wrapped in butcher paper and perfect eating on the fly. Opt for classic cheese, pepperoni, or our fave, artichoke and olive. _1124 W Grand Ave; 312-733-5456_

miniGuides.dek: With its iconic architecture, art, and nowadays, some of the best food in the country, Chicago is a city more than worthy of an extended visit. But if you find yourself with only a few hours here, it’s possible to get a taste (literally and figuratively) with this abridged plan of attack.
miniGuides.body:
[#image: /photos/548f07f6860c74c1162c98a2]|||
The Chicago Cultural Center's Beaux Arts-style exterior impresses, but its interior is the main attraction.
|||










##PLAY Here

__[Millennium Park](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/chicago/millennium-park)__ is the perfect place to stretch your legs while walking around the 24.5-acre grounds. Be sure to stop for your photo at Anish Kapoor's famous *Cloud Gate*(aka “The Bean”), marvel at Frank Gehry’s Pritzker Pavilion, and make faces at Crown Fountain (the interactive sculptures will make faces back, and beware—they spit).

Next, head across Michigan Avenue and duck into the __[Chicago Cultural Center](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/chicago/chicago-cultural-center)__. It was built in 1897 to house the first central Chicago library and today serves as a free cultural venue, hosting experimental dance, contemporary art, and live music (from chamber music to children’s concerts). A quick tour of the building will take you through rooms inspired by Florence’s Palazzo, Venice’s Palazzo Ducale, and Athens’ Acropolis. Don’t leave without getting a picture under the world’s largest stained glass Tiffany Dome.

##EAT Here

Legendary chef Rick Bayless has made Chicago home to a number of his restaurants, but a one-day trip is enough time to swing by __[Frontera Fresco](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/chicago/frontera-fresco)__ for a quick Mexican street food–inspired meal. Get a variety of tacos, especially the cochinita pibil, the roasted garlic mushroom, and the chipotle shrimp.

If you can’t stand the idea of passing through the city without having a slice of deep dish, stop by __[Giordano’s](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/chicago/giordano)__. The Millennium Park location of this Chicago institution can get crowded, so call ahead to expedite your meal.


[#image: /photos/548f670c860c74c1162c9d71]|||
Refuel at Intelligentsia Coffee. 
|||





##DRINK Here

__[Intelligentsia Coffee](http://www.cntraveler.com/bars/chicago/intelligentsia-coffee)__—a Chicago-based roaster, retailer, and coffee bar—now has six locations throughout the city, including one at Millennium Park. Refuel from a whirlwind visit to the city with a shot (or two) of their Black Cat Espresso.
miniGuides.socialTitle: How to Spend the Perfect Day in Chicago
miniGuides.seoDescription: With its iconic architecture, art, and arguably the best pizza and hot dogs in the country, Chicago is a city more than worthy of an extended visit. But if you find yourself with only a few hours here, it’s possible to get a taste of the city (literally and figuratively) with this abridged plan of attack.

fields.name: Lauren Kilberg
fields.shortBio: Collector of maps, passport stamps, and freckles.
fields.bio: Lauren Kilberg is a freelance writer and blogger residing in Chicago. Her travels have found her camping near the Pakistani border of India, conquering volcanoes in the Philippines and being humbled in Haiti. She spent two years living and working in South Korea before repatriating to the United States, but not before taking the six-month scenic route home via a backpacking trip from Indonesia to India. In short, she's a collector of maps, passport stamps, and freckles.

miniGuides.dek: To see Chicago at its best, plan a visit between early June and late September. (It probably won’t be snowing, but we’re not making any promises.) Here are a few tips for planning the perfect weekend in the Windy City.
miniGuides.seoDescription: To see Chicago at its best, plan a visit between early June and late September. (It probably won’t be snowing, but we’re not making any promises.) Here are a few tips for planning the perfect weekend in the Windy City.

miniGuides.body:
[#image: /photos/548f64c7860c74c1162c9d2e]|||
North Avenue Beach
|||







No one enjoys summer more than Chicagoites—after all, it’s their reward for surviving up to six months of tundra-like climates. So it’s no wonder that those few months are filled with locals out in the streets and parks, on rooftop bars, and crowding the lakeshore for beach volleyball, bike rides, and swimming. Here’s how you should experience the city in summertime like a true local. 


[#image: /photos/548f0bb2b6e03e8c2d0ccada]|||
The Langham Hotel Chicago
|||





##DAY 1: The Beach

__STAY__

Voted the top Chicago hotel by *Traveler*readers this year, __[The Langham](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/chicago/the-langham-chicago)__ delivers on location and luxury, occupying 13 floors of an iconic Mies van der Rohe skyscraper in the heart of downtown. Many of the suites come with views of the Chicago River.

For a different experience, __[Longman & Eagle](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/chicago/longman---eagle)__ in Logan Square (whose six rooms come with in-room cassette players and complimentary mix tapes) is a Chicago riff on the classic bed and breakfast—it’s the rare inn with a Michelin-starred restaurant and a Sunday doughnut shop…all steps from your bed.

__PLAY__

Pack a towel and swimsuit and find a spot along Chicago’s 27 miles of beaches. We recommend __[North Avenue Beach](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/chicago/north-avenue-beach)__, a great (albeit crowded) spot in Lincoln Park. Join a pick-up game of volleyball before grabbing a post-game bite at the beachside bar and grill Castaways (don't miss its burger or the shrimp ceviche). And try not to let the beach’s free Wi-Fi distract you from taking a dip—true, the water temperature is usually pretty brisk, but on a humid summer day, there’s nothing better. 

It’s also smart to plan a trip around one of the city’s summer festivals—there’s a never-ending lineup of events, though we love __[The Blues Festival](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/chicago/chicago-blues-festival)__ (the biggest free blues fest in the world, drawing the likes of Ray Charles and B.B. King over the years), the __[Jazz Festival](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/chicago/chicago-jazz-festival)__ (a Labor Day weekend tradition in the city), and __[Venetian Night](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/chicago/venetian-night)__ in early September. Grab a spot along the lakefront to watch the decorated, brightly lit boats parade by. 

__DRINK__

Chicagoans split their summer bar time between two spots: rooftop patios and brewpubs. Wind permitting, head to __[Drumbar](http://www.cntraveler.com/bars/chicago/drumbar)__, which is perched atop the Gold Coast–located Raffaello Hotel, 18 floors up; it’s a buzzy spot serving single-cask scotches along with views of Lake Michigan. Meanwhile, the cozy West Loop rooftop at __[Little Goat Diner](http://www.cntraveler.com/bars/chicago/little-goat-diner)__ is a favorite among residents for its rotating beer menu.


[#image: /photos/548f0bb7860c74c1162c98df]|||
Oysters at the Publican
|||





##Day 2: Go Shopping

__SHOP__

Chicago has a wealth of trendy boutiques, luxury lines, and art shops from River North to Lincoln Square, but Wicker Park/Bucktown has one of the best mixes of shops and wares (more on that in a minute). For luxury shopping, skip Michigan Avenue in favor of nearby __[Oak Street](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/chicago/oak-street)__ in the Gold Coast. Emporio Armani, Tom Ford, Jimmy Choo, Kate Spade, Carolina Herrera, Dolce & Gabbana, Christian Louboutin, and Hermès are just a few of the labels with addresses there.

__EAT__

If all you do on a visit to Chicago is eat, no one will blame you. The city’s food scene includes 24 Michelin-starred restaurants and hundreds more catering exclusively to Chicago’s famous staples of Italian beef, pizza, and hot dogs. __[The Publican](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/chicago/the-publican)__ won’t disappoint meat lovers (order the charcuterie plate and the suckling pig), nor will Big Star with its chorizo or pork belly tacos. __[GT Fish & Oyster](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/chicago/gt-fish-and-oyster)__ has an inventive menu perfect for sharing (don’t miss the oyster po’boy sliders with kimchi). If you’re really looking to splurge and don’t want to be disappointed, book tickets to three-star Alinea for a foray into chef Grant Achatz’s inimitable take on molecular gastronomy. 

__DRINK__

Time for a local beer: The big names in the Chicago microbrewery scene are Revolution Brewing, whose converted Logan Square warehouse is always packed (and deservingly so), and North Center–based Half Acre, where locals gather in the exposed-brick tap room to sample from the ever-changing lineup of suds; order the Daisy Cutter pale ale if you can.


[#image: /photos/548f64c7b6e03e8c2d0ccf0e]|||
Wicker Park
|||







##Day 3: Get Cultured 

__EXPLORE__

Since the 1960s, when the Chicago Imagists (painters Ed Paschke, Jim Nutt, and Roger Brown among them) attracted international attention with their shows at the Hyde Park Art Center, the city has been a breeding ground for emerging artists and innovative art dealers. Today the primary art gallery district is concentrated in River North—the area west of the Magnificent Mile and north of the Chicago River— where century-old redbrick warehouses have been converted into lofty exhibition spaces. More recently, a new generation of gallery owners has set up shop in the West Loop neighborhood, where you'll tend to find more cutting-edge work. Be sure to check out the __[Chicago Artists Coalition](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/chicago/chicago-artists-coalition)__, featuring more than 120 local artists, and __[Kavi Gupta Gallery](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/chicago/kavi-gupta-gallery)__, who (until very recently) was repping Theaster Gates, considered by many one of the most influential creators in the city.

Meanwhile, the gentrification of the __[Wicker Park/Bucktown](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/chicago/wicker-park-bucktown)__ area has led to a crop of new restaurants and bars, as well as new retailers that reflect the neighborhood's bohemian spirit. Mixed in with old neighborhood businesses (discount furniture stores, religious icon purveyors) is a range of galleries, clothing boutiques, and antique furniture shops like __[Salvage One](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/chicago/salvage-one)__ on Hubbard Street. Despite the hefty price tags in many of them, the neighborhood still has its charms. 

__SHOP__

To browse the best of Wicker Park/Bucktown, start at the Damen El stop on the Blue Line, and walk north along Damen Avenue to Armitage Avenue to scope out the trendiest shops: Futurgarb (men and women's clothing), Reckless Records (music), and Myopic Books (used books). If you have time, some stores are also scattered along Milwaukee Avenue south of North Avenue.

__PLAY__

No visit to Chicago, especially in the summer, would be complete without an architecture boat tour along the Chicago River. Book __[Chicago Architecture Foundation’s](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/chicago/chicago-architecture-foundation-river-cruise)__ 7:30 twilight cruise aboard Chicago’s First Lady to catch more than 50 of the city's architectural icons—Raymond Hood’s Gothic Revival Tribune Tower among them—as the sun sets. It’s a perfect post-dinner activity.

fields.name: Lauren Kilberg

related.hed: 10 Free Things to Do in Chicago
related.dek: There's a common misconception that travel in big cities requires a big budget, but that's definitely not true about Chicago. Many of the city's best attractions (and a few of its hidden gems) don't cost a penny. From a world-class zoo to the work of renowned artists, here are 10 free things to do in Chicago.
related.seoTitle: 10 Free Things to Do in Chicago
related.socialTitle: 10 Free Things to Do in Chicago

items.title: Chicago Greeter Program
items.caption: Completely free and customized guided tours are available through the [Chicago Greeter](http://chicagogreeter.com/) program. More than 200 proud Chicagoans volunteer to give 2-4 hour tours that are customized by the group's interests. To guarantee a spot, be sure to reserve your tour at least 10 days prior to arriving.

items.title: Millennium Park
items.caption: [This 24.5-acre park](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/chicago/millennium-park) located between the Loop and the Lake Michigan houses some of Chicago's most iconic structures, including the Jay Pritzker Pavilion, designed by world-renowned architect Frank Gehry. During the summer the theater hosts [Grant Park Music Festival](http://www.grantparkmusicfestival.com), a 10-week free classical music series. The focal point of the park is ​Cloud Gate​ (better known as The Bean), a sculpture by artist Anish Kapoor. During winter the McCormick Tribune Ice Rink​ is open to the public: it's free if you have your own skates, otherwise they are available to rent for $12.

items.title: Chicago Cultural Center
items.caption: The [Chicago Cultural Center](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/chicago/chicago-cultural-center) has been a city landmark since 1897. Originally the central library branch, today it serves as a community space and hosts a packed calendar of events from free art exhibits​ and lectures​ to theater, dance​,​ and musical performances. If those aren't your thing, it's still worth walking through just to marvel at the interior architecture​, which includes marble and glass mosaics, a grand staircases, stained glass, as well as a 38-foot Tiffany glass dome that remains the largest of its kind in the world.

items.title: Beaches
items.caption: From Memorial Day to Labor Day you can enjoy Chicago's 26-miles of sandy Lake Michigan shore. With more than [25 beaches](http://www.cpdbeaches.com/) to choose from, there's a spot for everyone. Oak Street beach offers hard to beat views of the Chicago skyline. If you're traveling with your pet, head to Montrose Beach. It's the city's largest and home to a sandy dog park. [North Avenue Beach](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/chicago/north-avenue-beach) is a great place to join a pick-up game of volleyball and it makes a beautiful viewing spot for the free [Chicago Air and Water Show](https://www.cityofchicago.org/city/en/depts/dca/supp_info/chicago_air_and_watershow.html) in August.

items.title: Navy Pier
items.caption: Arguably the city's most touristy attraction, but as a free activity [Navy Pier](http://navypier.com/) is worth a visit. The 3,300-foot long pier extends from Chicago's lakeshore and offers a variety of sights and activities for families. Some of the pier's major attractions cost money, like riding the 150-foot Ferris wheel, the Chicago Children's Museum, and cruising on one of the many boat tours that dock there. However, entry to the pier itself is free, as is the indoor botanical garden within the Crystal Gardens, a six-story glass atrium near the end of the pier. During summer there's a free fireworks show every Wednesday and Saturday night, as well as a summer concert series held at the [The LandShark Beer Garden](http://www.chicagosbestbeergarden.com/).

items.title: Buckingham Fountain
items.caption: With a capacity to hold 1.5 million gallons of water, the [Clarence F. Buckingham Memorial Fountain](http://www.chicagoparkdistrict.com/parks/clarence-f-buckingham-memorial-fountain/) (just call it Buckingham Fountain when you visit) is one of the world's largest. Located in Grant Park, the fountain performs water shows every hour ​on the hour ​between 9 AM and 10 PM (times vary)​. The water display is powered by 134 jets that pump  approximately 14,100 gallons of water per minute. The display lasts 20 minutes and is accompanied by a light show after dusk. Much to ​the envy of ​many Chicagoan​s​, Buckingham Fountain goes into "hibernation" each winter but resumes ​its ​performances in April.

items.title: Garfield Park Conservatory
items.caption: Located on the city's west side, the conservatory occupies 4.5 acres of the 184-acre Garfield Park. More than 100 years old, [Garfield Park Conservatory](http://garfield-conservatory.org/index.html) hosts a variety of permanent plant exhibits and today remains one of the largest conservatories of its kind in the world. Display houses are organized by theme and include the Desert House, Fern Room, Palm House, a children's garden, and the Aroid House featuring glass lily pads by famed artist Dale Chihuly.

items.title: Lincoln Park Zoo
items.caption: The zoo first opened its gates in 1868 in Chicago's Lincoln Park neighborhood and remains one of the oldest zoos in the country. More than 1,000 animals from 200 different species call [Lincoln Park Zoo](http://www.lpzoo.org) home. Exhibits include bears, birds, and primates, as well as a sea lion pool that houses the zoo's harbor seals. Be sure to catch one of the annual events, like [ZooLights](http://www.lpzoo.org/events/calendar/zoolights) during the winter holiday season and the corresponding [BrewLights](http://www.lpzoo.org/events/calendar/brewlights), held for the first time in 2014, for the 21-and-over crowd.

items.title: Festivals
items.caption: Summer is festival season in Chicago and the [Department of Cultural Affairs and Special Events](http://www.cityofchicago.org/city/en/depts/dca.html) offers a packed season of free performances and events throughout the city.​ ​Every year the​ ​[Chicago Blues​ ​Festival​](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/chicago/chicago-blues-festival) is the world's largest free blues festival​ ​and has included past performances by Ray Charles, B.B. King, Bo Diddley,​ ​and​ ​Buddy Guy​. [Chicago Jazz Festival](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/chicago/chicago-jazz-festival) is held on Labor Day weekend. ​At the end of May comes the [Chicago Gospel Music Festival](http://www.cityofchicago.org/city/en/depts/dca/supp_info/chicago_gospel_musicfestival.html), and  the [World Music Festival](http://www.cityofchicago.org/city/en/depts/dca/supp_info/world_music_festival.html/) is held for 11 days in September.

items.title: Museums
items.caption:
Chicago is home to superb museums featuring collections and exhibits to interest anyone. Most of the city's museums offer discount days with free admission to Illinois residents, active-duty military personnel, and Illinois K-12 teachers. The [City Gallery](http://www.cityofchicago.org/city/en/depts/dca/supp_info/city_gallery_in_thehistoricwatertower.html) in the Historic Water Tower on Michigan Avenue is always free, as is the [Museum of Contemporary Photography](http://www.mocp.org/) and the [National Museum of Mexican Art](http://www.nationalmuseumofmexicanart.org/).
 
Days and admission discounts vary, so it's best to check the museum's website prior to visiting.  

Museum Discount Days:
​[Field Museum](http://www.fieldmuseum.org/at-the-field/programs/discount-days),  [​Art Institute​ of Chicago](http://www.artic.edu/visit?qt-reference_nodes=1#quicktabs-reference_nodes),
[​Shedd Aquarium](http://www.sheddaquarium.org/plan-a-visit/special-offers/), [Museum of Science and Industry​​](http://www.msichicago.org/visit-the-museum/museum-info/admission/free-days/), and the [Adler Planetarium](http://www.adlerplanetarium.org/admission-passes/?rq=discount%20days)

related.hed: Chicago’s Most High-Tech Hotel Isn’t Its Newest
related.dek: It’s not Chicago’s newest hotel, but the Peninsula just kicked off a major revamp that will position it as the most tech-forward in the city and across the brand.
related.body:
[#image: /photos/559d56b17772ff921f95b40f]||||||


Luxury at the 339-room [Peninsula Chicago](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/chicago/the-peninsula--chicago) used to come in the form of a rich palette of gold, plaid and dark wood. But the gadgetry, a boxy bedside system that controlled everything from the A/C to the TV, wasn't quite as up-to-date. But now, that's all changing: The hotel recently unveiled its latest iteration of opulence with a major room renovation featuring a mod white interior design, along with a sweeping tablet-driven technology system. One floor of rooms is nearly complete with the rest slated to be finished by April 2016, at which point this Chicago classic might just become the city’s most high-tech hotel.

The biggest change: A new tablet system that allows you to control virtually every facet of the in-room experience, including the thermostat, lighting, music, HD TV programming, and room service, the last of which is the latest upgrade to the custom Peninsula software. Revamped rooms will come equipped with three or more tablets, both desk side and bedside.

Other, smaller upgrades are more about making your life on the road a little easier. Forgot your mobile charger at home? Open the nightstand drawer and choose from one of several options covering the most recent smartphone generations, already plugged in and ready to roll. Or skip any possible room charges with VOIP-enabled phones, which allow for free international calls via the Internet. And if you don't want to lug a tablet—or three—around your room all day, that’s where a new set of LED panels come in handy. Positioned throughout each room, these touch-screens control many of the same functions, including valet calls, thermostat controls, and privacy options. Plus, thanks to a new partnership between Peninsula hotels and Beats by Dre, you'll also soon have access to products like their wireless headphones, sweat- and water-resistant wireless earphones for use in the fitness center, and an in-room speaker to create your own vacation soundtrack. 


[#image: /photos/559d57d60121edec256ffe84]||||||





Much of the hotel’s new design takes inspiration from the gorgeous [Peninsula Shanghai](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/marana/peninsula-shanghai), among the brand’s best known (and most revered) properties. You'll see it in the sleek closet spaces featuring the brand’s signature luggage bench, and in useful amenities, such as an eye-level mini fridge disguised as a pretty cabinet. 

Still, some of the most beautiful elements of the redesigned rooms nod right back to Chicago. Lake Michigan blue adds a touch of color while subtle waves bring texture to white bed duvets. The chrysanthemum, the official flower of Chicago and one of the four noble flowers of Asia, also shows up as a giant work of art in every room, with suites featuring a hand-embroidered version. 

*This article has been updated with new information about the tablet system.*

fields.name: Nina Kokotas Hahn
fields.shortBio: Nina Kokotas Hahn is a writer and editor based in Chicago.
fields.bio: Daughter of a travel agent and a sucker for a challenge, Nina answers the call for adventure. She covers everything from new Chicago dining and hotels to family travel, destination marathons, and far-flung safaris. She’s proud to launch her travels from Chicago, where she lives with her husband and two children.

related.hed: How to Act Like a Local in Chicago
related.dek: Chicago is a city that greets visitors with a big Midwest welcome and very few rules to follow. With that being said, heeding these few tips will have you blending in like a local and getting about the Second City like it’s your second home.
related.body:
[#image: /photos/546a44a8cbbd2620680da2b8]|||
We will allow you one photo beneath The Bean in Millennium Park. But just one!
|||







##How to Greet Someone

Born-and-raised Chicagoans definitely speak with an accent, but not everyone sounds like the superfans made famous by *Saturday Night Live* ("daaaaa Bears"). Most importantly, Chicago is a friendly city. No matter how you greet someone, just don’t hesitate to do so. Strike up conversation or ask a local for directions and your efforts will be rewarded. 

##How to Get Around

Take public transportation. Chicago’s ‘L,’ or elevated train, is as much an icon of the city as deep-dish pizza or [The Bean](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/chicago/millennium-park). Buy a Ventra ticket from the vending machine located at station entrances, swipe your card, and ride. If you’re visiting the city for a few days, consider purchasing a multi-day ticket for unlimited rides for the extent of your stay.

[Divvy](https://www.divvybikes.com/), Chicago’s bike-sharing system, is another great way to get around. Thousands of blue bikes are available for rent—daily, all year round—at hundreds of stations across the city. The system is designed for short trips (30 minutes or less), so it’s not recommended for an all-day bike tour along Lake Michigan. Twenty-four-hour passes cost $7 and will earn you unlimited 30-minute rides. If you get lost or decide to take the scenic route, you’ll be charged a nominal overtime fee.

##What to Wear

Chicago has four extreme seasons and weather can be predictably unpredictable during all of them. Wind chill, humidity, extreme temperatures, and lake-effect snow dictate how locals dress—and it often ends up being more utilitarian and practical than fashion forward. No matter the season, pack layers. If you’re visiting in winter, pack even more layers. Between November and the end of February, you'll blend right in with a knee-length down coat, preferably with a hood. Warm and walkable winter boots are a must, like a pair of Sorels or Columbia Bugaboots. No matter what season you're visiting, know that Chicago is an eclectic city, and so to is the dress code. The unifying trend is casual and comfortable. Wear what you’d like, as long as it’s not a Cardinals or Packers jersey.

##Locals Do's and Don'ts

__Do__ eat a Chicago-style hot dog with all the fixings. While you won’t be judged for doing so at Portillo’s, arguably the most touristy of hot dog spots, don’t be afraid to give your business to just about any shop with a Vienna Beef sign glowing in the window. Where you go is less important than how you go about it. Whatever you do, [don’t put ketchup on a Chicago dog.](http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2013-12-23/what-not-to-do-in-chicago/3)

__Do__ eat something besides the city’s staples. Chicago is home to 24 Michelin-starred restaurants, two of which (repeat-earner Alinea and first-timer Grace) earned three stars.    

__Don't__ limit yourself to Michigan Avenue, Museum Campus, and Navy Pier.

__Do__ visit at least one of Chicago’s museums. Right now, the can't-miss exhibit is [David Bowie Is](http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2014-11-12/bye-bye-bowie-the-10-exhibits-to-see-before-they-close/4)—a collection of the musician's photographs, storyboards, and sketches of his wild costumes and set designs—on display at the Museum of Contemporary Art Chicago through January 4.

__Don't__ be afraid to swim in Lake Michigan. The water's fine, weather permitting. Chicago has some 27 beaches along the lake, and [all the cool kids go paddleboarding.](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2013-08-14/paddleboarding-lake-michigan-chicago)

__Don't__ take the Seadog speedboat sightseeing tour from Navy Pier—opt for the more leisurely [Chicago Architecture Foundation River Cruise](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/chicago/chicago-architecture-foundation-river-cruise) to hear about the city’s history and take in its famous skyline. For a cold-weather alternative, opt for a Pedway tour (not to be mistaken with a Segway Tour—don’t do that). A Pedway tour will bring you beneath the city (no wind) on an informative walking tour of Chicago’s underground corridors.

related.hed: Soho House Chicago, By the Numbers
related.dek: How does the new Soho House Chicago, the brand’s largest property yet, stack up against its exclusive brethren? We’ve broken the hotel down by the numbers.
related.body:
[#image: /photos/53ff9a1081424d9d655bd54f]||||||





The sheer size of the newly-opened [Soho House Chicago](http://www.sohohousechicago.com/), located inside a 108,000-square-foot former belt factory, is enough to impress guests. But the West Loop property (the brand’s largest to date) also offers floor after floor of impeccable design in the form of antique furniture and modern artwork—plus amenities galore. We got the exclusive on how the House adds up, treasure by treasure. Good luck getting in to see it, though...


__Total bottles of alcohol being stocked:__ 200 bottles in the club bar, with 50 bottles of whiskey and 20 bottles of gin and vodka in the tavern. Approximately 8,000 drinks were enjoyed the first week.


[#image: /photos/53ff9a1a81424d9d655bd55e]||||||


__Blankets available for guests to use on the roof, in the on-site movie theater, and elsewhere:__ Approximately 230.


__Pieces of artwork hanging on the walls:__ Approximately 270.


__Pieces of artwork by Chicago artists:__ Approximately 150.


__[Spa services](http://www.sohohousechicago.com/cowshed-spa) available:__ 57, with more to be added soon.


__Film screenings at the movie theater:__ four nights per week, three of which are pre-release films.


[#image: /photos/53ff9a22a5a7650f3959dac6]||||||


__The perimeter around the hotel pool:__ 144 ft.


__Panes of glass surrounding the rooftop pool:__ 192.


[#image: /photos/53ff9a1aa5a7650f3959dab7]||||||


__Ceramic or vintage chickens in the Chicken Shop:__ 62.


__Vintage crystal decanters in the Soho Tavern:__ 45.


__Light bulbs on the rooftop canopy lights:__ 396.


__Starting price of a [hotel room](http://www.sohohousechicago.com/rooms):__ $240.


__Year that The Allis Building was commissioned:__ 1907.


__Number of barns that furnished the reclaimed wood used throughout the House:__ More than ten.


[#image: /photos/53ff9a2281424d9d655bd56d]||||||

__Number of Parisian chandeliers hanging in The Allis:__ six.

__Number of elementary school gyms that furnished the hardwood floor found at [the gym](http://www.sohohousechicago.com/gymnasium):__ one.


[#image: /photos/53ff9a10a5a7650f3959daa8]||||||

fields.name: Jourdan Fairchild
fields.shortBio: Jourdan Fairchild is a Chicago-based writer, editor, and creative consultant with a love for travel, design, food, and crafts.
fields.bio: [Jourdan Fairchild](http://www.jourdanfairchild.com) has spent the last decade working as a writer and editor for national magazines and websites. She began her career in New York at *In Style*, then held staff positions at Oprah's former home magazine (*O at Home*) as well as *Country Living*. After moving to Chicago with her husband in 2012, she worked as the Chicago editor of DailyCandy until the website closed. She's the author of *Fly DIY: Crafts for the Modern Traveler*, and her work has appeared in *Chicago Sun-Times, Southern Living, Budget Travel*, Design*Sponge, and more.
